data.title: Unaudited Interim Results
data.full_content:
27 Sep 2022 07:00
RNS Number : 6984A
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
27 September 2022
For release: 07.00, 27 September 2022
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or the "Company")
Unaudited Interim Results
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) announces that it has today published its unaudited Interim Results for the six months ended 30 June 2022 with respect to the Company and its subsidiaries (the "Group").
Nelson Law, Executive Chairman of the Company commented:
"
Our proven capabilities in acting as a bridge between European merchants, mainly of accessible but luxury items, and Chinese consumers, means that we remain excellently placed to continue benefitting from the growing popularity of ecommerce, particularly in China, and changing behaviors in the ecommerce ecosystem. Our commercial and logistical systems and infrastructure are in place and are capable of adapting to rapid changes in ecommerce trends and behaviours. Our strong ties with Tmall, and with merchants of high quality goods, will also contribute to our continued success
."
-Ends-
Enquiries:
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
Law Chung Lam Nelson, Executive Chairman
+ 44 (0) 753 795 9788
Novum Securities Limited
David Coffman
+ 44 (0) 20 7399 9400
Notes to Editors:
The Company's Shares are traded on the Official List of the London Stock Exchange's main market for listed securities under the ticker SCGL.
Further information on Sealand is available on its website
http://www.scg-ltd.com/
SEALAND CAPITAL GALAXY LIMITED
MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited is a company acting as a special purpose acquisition company. The Group is engaged in digital marketing, mobile payment and other IT related business. Today it announces its results for the six months ended 30 June 2022.
Business Review
Since April 2020, the Covid-19 pandemic had a significant negative impact on the Group's business, but the Group is pleased to report that is has now turned a corner, notwithstanding the other new challenges facing virtually all economies, such as high energy prices, inflation, and slowing growth rates.
The Group's presence on Tmall, via products for which it has exclusive licences in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau, continues to drive profits. These include Carter Beauty, Czech & Speake, Heath London, HH Simonsen, Inari, Living Garden Honey, Missguided Beauty, Silllk Aromas Beauty, and The Gruff Stuff. Tmall is a leading Chinese-language website for business-to-consumer online retail, allowing local Chinese and international businesses to sell brand name goods to consumers in greater China.
The Group is delighted to report that its ecommerce segment delivered a profit of £13,118. Although many shoppers have been eager to leave the house and return to stores where they are able, behaviour patterns have changed since the onset of the pandemic. Online shopping has come to serve a distinct purpose, and the Directors believe this trend will continue in the long term. Consumers can have whatever they want, whenever they want it, on-demand and digitally. Shoppers increasingly expect e-retailers to provide a sophisticated, personalised shopping experience, which the Group is successfully doing.
In addition, the way in which we present information to online shoppers mirrors consumers' increasing time conducting research. Simply put, we are providing more information for shoppers. There is now a greater emphasis on the shopper researching everything about a product in order to make an informed decision.
The type of goods that we offer to shoppers are also precisely the type of items we consider they are currently seeking online. Just as we saw in the aftermath of the 2007 financial crisis, consumers appear to be putting very large purchases on hold, while continuing to spend on small luxuries such as upscale cosmetics brands, and other daily luxury items which they consider affordable. This trend is in line with the brands for which we have exclusive licences, and we expect to see this to continue into 2023.
The momentum for online shopping is now considered to be unstoppable and we continue to keep a strong focus on the evolution of digital buying. For example, livestream shopping (i.e. brands using livestreams to promote and sell products) is picking up speed, and we continue to monitor advances to ensure that our capabilities match the modern digital marketplace which consumers continue to expect.
Our work with influencers in China has also proven to be the correct strategy and continues to underpin our success. Younger generations find authenticity and trust in different places than older generations; predominantly they trust their peers and they trust influencers.
Financial Review
During the six months ended 30 June 2022, the loss attributable to ordinary shareholders was £226,910 (2021: £98,643), and the revenue for the period was £76,071 (2021: £39,184). The loss has widened because of an accrual of director's fees of £99,

SEALAND CAPITAL GALAXY LIMITED
CHAIRMAN'S STATEMENT
Dear Shareholders
I hereby present the annual report of Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (the "Company" or "Sealand", together with its subsidiaries, the "Group") for the year ended 31 December 2021 (the "Year").
PERFORMANCE FOR THE YEAR
The Group reported a loss of £1,026,639 (2020: £525,156) during the Year. Our business was continuously impacted by the COVID-19 epidemic over our overseas subsidiaries' operations during the Year. The Group's revenue for the Year decreased by 74.34% to £177,667 (2020: £692,410) following the closure of one of our major customers related to the Group's digital marketing segment.
Despite this the Group was able to make certain achievements in successfully launching certain consumer brands on a global direct sales platform.
KEY DEVELOPMENTS FOR THE YEAR
The Company, through one of its wholly owned subsidiaries, has successfully deepened its presence on Tmall by securing and launching a number of consumer brands on the Tmall Global Direct Sales Brand Stations, including Carter Beauty, Czech & Speake, Heath London, HH Simonsen, Inari, Living Garden Honey, Missguided Beauty, Silllk Aromas Beauty, and The Gruff Stuf. Tmall is a leading Chinese-language website for business-to-consumer online retail, allowing local Chinese and international businesses to sell brand name goods to consumers in greater China. After entry on the Tmall Global Direct Sales Brand Station, the Group believed that our brands would have far greater exposure to online shoppers.
FUTURE PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK
The COVID continued to have serious impact on various economies that the Group operates. We are now leveraging our partner relationships with Tmall to build bridges between Chinese consumers and European merchants of high quality brands. We continue to believe that our ability to offer commercial and logistical solutions to businesses in a world that is certainly moving ever more rapidly towards online shopping and away from physical stores will be critical for the growth of the business.
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
We wish to express our appreciation to our shareholders, business partners and suppliers for their continued support during what has been a difficult time for all. We would like to thank our dedicated staff for their contributions to the success of the Group.
Chung Lam Nelson Law
Chairman

data.title: New brand engagement and brand station launch
data.full_content:
9 Nov 2021 07:00
RNS Number : 7219R
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
09 November 2021
For release: 9 November 2021
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or "the Company")
New Brand Engagement and Launch on Tmall Global Brand Station
New Brand Engagement
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) announces that it has successfully secured two new brand distribution contracts. The first is for Silllk Aromas Beauty in mainland China. The second is for Missguided Beauty in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau ("greater China"). The Company is delighted to add these two brands to its growing brand portfolio.
Atelier Aroma by Silllk Aromas Beauty is formulated and blended in the UK and is a skin and body care brand containing essential oils which are natural and are of the highest therapeutic grade.
Missguided Beauty is a global beauty brand targeted at millennials.
It is a popular brand of makeup,
evolved from the Missguided Masterbrand in 2020, and was established in the UK by the fragrance powerhouse Per-scent.
Tmall Global Brand Station
Sealand is also delighted to announce that the Company has further deepened its presence on Tmall by successfully launching three consumer brands on the Tmall Global Direct Sales Brand Station. Tmall is a leading Chinese-language website for business-to-consumer online retail, allowing local Chinese and international businesses to sell brand name goods to consumers in greater China. To give an indication of its scale;
From 1 November to 11 November 2020 the total turnover of the Tmall global carnival season, which traditionally runs over that period, was RMB 498.2 billion (approximately USD 74.1 billion) and the total number of orders was 2.321 billion.
Three of the various brands for which the Company has exclusive distribution rights in greater China i.e. Living Garden, Inari, and The Gruff Stuff, have been introduced on the Tmall Global Direct Sales platform:
Tmall Global Super Market
.
Tmall Global Super Market is a self-owned direct sales store of Tmall and has approximately 30 million upwardly mobile loyal followers with considerable purchasing power. It is a strong brand development tool, especially for new brands in the greater Chinese market. After entry on the Tmall Global Direct Sales Brand Station; Living Garden, Inari, and The Gruff Stuff brands will have far greater exposure to online shoppers. It is also estimated that the brand's products will receive ten times more unique views than they would have received on the Tmall flagship store, where they are already available. This new arrangement will benefit and speed up sales progress and will increase gross merchandise volumes of the brands for the Company.
Nelson Law, Executive Chairman of the Company, commented:
"We continue to build bridges between Chinese consumers and European merchants of desirable, high quality brands and are very pleased to have added Sillk Aromas Beauty London and Missguided Beauty to our growing range of European brands for which we hold distribution rights."
Law added:
"The Tmall Global Super Market is an efficient tool, and a cost effective way to promote brands and products during their incubation period in the Chinese market. It allows for accelerated initial brand building and brand awareness among consumers. The presence of Living Garden, Inari, and The Gruff Stuff on the Tmall Global Super Market will also allow us to engage well known tier one Key Opinion Leaders, otherwise known as influencers, for live stream sales, which will assist in boosting consumer purchases. Tier one Key Opinion Leaders have A-list celebrity profiles in greater China and can significantly augment product sales by association."
-Ends-

data.title: Issue of Equity and Grant of Options
data.full_content:
21 Oct 2021 07:00
RNS Number : 7345P
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
21 October 2021
For immediate release: 21st October 2021
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or "the Company")
Issue of Equity and Grant of Options
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) announces that it
has agreed to issue 77,142,857 new ordinary shares to its Executive Chairman,
Law Chung Lam Nelson, in return for the partial conversion of the loan owed by the Company to him. The conversion price per share is 0.7p, being the closing mid- price on 18 October 2021, making a total conversion of £540,000. The Board of the Company welcomes this transaction as being an important step in strengthening the balance sheet of the Company and preserving the Company's cash. The loan outstanding to Mr Law now stands at £247,081.
Similarly, the Company has also agreed to issue 714,286 ordinary shares at the same price per share to a company associated with the Non- Executive Director of the Company, Geoffrey Griggs, in consideration for professional services rendered, in lieu of a cash payment.
Application will be made for the 77,857,143 new ordinary shares to be admitted to trading which is expected to be on or around 26 October 2021. The new ordinary shares will rank pari passu with the existing ordinary shares of the Company. Following the issue of the new ordinary shares, the Company's issued share capital will comprise of 595,694,385 ordinary shares. This figure of 595,694,385 ordinary shares may be used by shareholders in the Company as the denominator for the calculations by which they will determine if they are required to notify their interest in, or a change in their interest in, the share capital of the Company under the FCA's Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules.
In addition, the Company has
granted 105,122,538 share options under the Company's Employee Incentive Scheme (the "Options") to its Directors and other staff as set out below.
The share options to be granted were proposed by the remuneration committee and approved by the Board as part of the Company's programme of share option grants in order to incentivise the members of the Board and other valued staff members. The options are exercisable between one and four years from the date of grant (or earlier at the discretion of the Board) at a strike price of 0.7p. The share options awarded are as follows:
·
Law Chung Lam Nelson, Executive Chairman
35,040,846
·
Geoffrey Griggs, Non-Executive Director 35,040,846
·
Seven key members of staff have also been granted options over 35,040,846 shares in total
Following the grant of the share options outlined above, the total share options outstanding will be 105,122,538 representing 17.6% of the 595,694,385 ordinary shares in issue.
This announcement contains information which, prior to its disclosure, was inside information as stipulated under Regulation 11 of the Market Abuse (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019/310 (as amended).

data.title: Launch of Heath London Tmall Global Flagship store
data.full_content:
11 Oct 2021 07:00
RNS Number : 5639O
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
11 October 2021
For release: 11 October 2021
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or "the Company")
Launch of Heath London Tmall Global Flagship store
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) is delighted to announce that the Company has launched the
Heath London Tmall Global Flagship store
on
Tmall.com,
a leading Chinese-language website for business-to-consumer (B2C) online retail that allows local Chinese and international businesses to sell brand name goods to consumers in mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau (together "Greater China")
. On 23 July 2021, Sealand announced that it had entered into an exclusive distribution contract with Heath London, a British male skincare brand, in Greater China
.
The flagship Store was officially launched on 25 September 2021.
The demand for male skincare products in China continues to grow. According to Tmall sales data, the value of male skincare products sold in 2020 exceeded RMB 300 million. Certain individual products recorded an annual growth of 15-20%, with some British and other European male skincare brands recording annual sales of RMB 5 million to RMB 10 million within in their first year on the Tmall e-commerce platform.
Nelson Law, Executive Chairman of the Company commented:
"Heath London is a new range of grooming solutions inspired by the urban natural lifestyle and incorporates modern, pioneering formulations that deliver fast results. We are delighted to bring Heath London's unique products to the online Chinese market with the launch of
the Heath London Tmall Global Flagship store on
Tmall.com, following the exclusive distribution agreement that we signed with Heath London over the summer. This is the latest development in our
strategy to build a bridge between European merchants of desirable, high end goods and sophisticated Chinese consumers with global taste. COVID-19 has accelerated changes in consumer buying habits. More and more Chinese consumers, as elsewhere in the world, are looking to buy niche luxury and quality products on-line, and we remain excellently placed to take advantage of these trends."
-Ends-

data.title: Exclusive Distribution Contracts Update
data.full_content:
31 Aug 2021 07:00
RNS Number : 0833K
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
31 August 2021
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or "the Company")
Exclusive Distribution Contracts Update
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) is pleased to announce that it has entered an
exclusive, three-year product-specific distribution contract with ITP Bulgaria Ltd ("ITP") to become the sole distributor of ITP's Living Garden Honey brand in Hong Kong, Macau, and mainland China ("the territories"). The Company will sell ​​Living Garden Honey (the "Honey") online through its England Pie Tmall flagship store, through other local networks, and will actively explore further offline sales channels. The Company also plans to sell the Honey through Harvey Nichols in Hong Kong where the Company is already an authorised supplier of certain other fine European goods.
According to sales data from Tmall,
the major Chinese-language website for business-to-consumer online retail,
the total amount of honey sold through the platform in 2020 was RMB 1.2 billion, an increase of 51% over 2019. Imported honey accounts for about 30% of total market sales on Tmall.
Living Garden Honey is a brand of natural and
organic Bulgarian honey
. The mono-floral honeys are extracted by cold pressing methods. The Honey is raw, unfiltered, unheated, sugar free, additive free, GMO-free, unpasteurized, and contains nothing artificial. As such the Honey preserves the natural aroma, nutritional value, and fine taste of natural honey.
Bulgarian honey combines several unique honey types of certain valuable and healing meadow plants such as acacia, lime, thyme, and lavender. An increasing amount of Bulgarian honey is also certified as "bio". By the number of organic certified bee families, Bulgaria ranks first in Europe, with prerequisites for this certification that include clean and protected natural environments.
Nelson Law, Executive Chairman of the Company commented:
"Living Garden Honey is the latest premium European brand for which we are the exclusive distributor in Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China. Other brands include HH Simonsen, Inari, Czech & Speake, The Gruff Stuff, Heath London and Carter Beauty by Melissa Carter. We will continue to add more names alongside these, as demand for quality, niche European products in China continues to increase. We plan to engage with more merchants, especially at trade shows - whether virtual or in person - with a view to enter further exclusive distributor contracts. Our sales experience, scale and sophisticated digital infrastructure allows us to offer various packages to potential sellers in the Chinese market to test a product's popularity. We can offer creative and flexible ways for a merchant to access our services to establish whether it would be beneficial for the merchant to enter into a full-scale distribution contract, and we invite purveyors of European brands who are looking to expand into China to contact us."
-Ends-

Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited

Harvey Nichols Hong Kong Supplier Contracts
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) is pleased to announce that it has signed
a contract with Harvey Nichols to become an authorised supplier in Hong Kong. Brands currently signed to Sealand's marketing and distribution services will now be made available in Harvey Nichols Hong Kong's stores for official sale.
Initially, three brands, HH Simonsen, Inari and Czech & Speake, have been launched at Beyond Beauty at Harvey Nichols Landmark and Pacific Place stores with a digital advertising and promotional campaign to back the launch. Sealand will launch three further brands, The Gruff Stuff, Heath London and

Nelson Law, Executive Chairman of the Company commented:
"Sealand is busy winning new clients who want access to our digital and traditional marketing and distribution expertise. There is huge appetite in China and the territories for high quality niche European brands. Being able to promote our clients' brands at Harvey Nichols is massively important for our target consumers. Harvey Nichols is a respected and renowned global retail brand, famous for its unique fashion goods and window displays. It has 16 branches around the world, and among them is its Landmark store in Hong Kong, which covers an area of more than 60,000 square feet over five floors. Since opening in Hong Kong in 2005, Harvey Nichols Landmark store has become a pilgrimage for celebrities and fashion lovers with its diversified taste trend."

data.title: Distribution Contracts Signed
data.full_content:
23 Jul 2021 07:00
RNS Number : 1983G
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
23 July 2021
For immediate release: 23 July 2021
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or "the Company")
Exclusive Distribution Contracts
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) is pleased to announce that it has entered into
exclusive, three years product-specific distribution contracts with Heath London, The Gruff Stuff and Carter Beauty by Melissa Carter in Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China ("the territories").
Heath London ("Heath") is a new British brand, which brings together the skincare demands of the busy urban man in a carefully curated range that helps protect skin from external pollution. Heath's products are already selling in Peter Jones, Beast., Harvey Nichols, Fortnum & Mason, John Lewis, Selfridges & Co, John Bell & Croyden. Sealand, through its subsidiary company SCG Group Limited, will now distribute to the territories using its established routes to market; developed e-commerce and retail channels; and backed by its digital marketing expertise.
The Gruff Stuff is an award-winning premium British, vegan brand offering genderless and inclusive skincare. Their aim is to develop products that are results-driven, easy to use, and suitable for everyone. Consumers are also drawn to the fact that their ingredients are ethically and responsibly sourced. The Gruff Stuff
is now available in more than 30 countries and was the most awarded brand at the Pure Beauty Awards in 2020.
Originating in Ireland, Carter Beauty by Melissa Carter combines professional-quality beauty products with branding created for the social media generation. Carter Beauty's mantra is, "Beauty shouldn't leave you broke" and it is a cruelty-free company that prides itself on being a Peta-approved member of 'Beauty Without Bunnies'. Carter Beauty is the first Irish
cosmetics brand to have secured an instore listing in Walmart and
has launched across 1500 Walmart stores in 47 states in the US.
Sealand and its subsidiaries have now been successful in securing exclusive
distribution contracts with eight premium UK and European brands. The team will continue to target more niche and high-quality brands with the goal of becoming the partner of choice brands to establish a foothold in the Chinese market, where there is great demand for high quality non-Chinese products.
Nelson Law, executive Chairman will lend the Company $HK 2 million ("the loan") to help support these new initiatives and to facilitate the e-commerce platform. The loan will be made available for draw down over a period of the next three months, is unsecured, carries no interest and has no fixed term.
Nelson Law, Executive Chairman of the Company commented:
"COVID-19 has accelerated the change in consumer buying habits and more and more Chinese consumers, as elsewhere in the world, are looking to buy niche luxury and quality products on-line. We are extremely proud to have become the exclusive distributor of these three highly desirable brands in
the territories
.
"Heath London and The Gruff Stuff appeals to a new type of Far Eastern consumer. Young, urban professionals in the territories are increasingly aligned with their contemporaries in other sophisticated markets when it comes to responsible skincare that is inoffensive to the environment and is not marketed along traditional gender lines. Furthermore, The Gruff Stuff only uses packaging made of recycled plastics and paper, encouraging responsible disposal of both and the whole range is vegan and free from gluten, parabens and mineral oils. Products from The Gruff Stuff serve a growing, conscious market and we are very excited to bring this brand to the territories.
"Similarly, Carter Beauty by Melissa Carter taps into the visual culture created by social media, with beautiful packaging, and combines its offering with an environmentally friendly product and narrative. The profile of this product and its strong visual identity dovetails with our strengths; our digital marketing and 'influencers' services which we employ in order to build a bridge between European merchants and consumers in Asia."
-Ends-

on

Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL), announces that it has today published its Annual Report and Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2020 with respect to the Company and its subsidiaries (the "Group"). £
525,156 (2019:
£
1,481,629) and increasing Group revenue by 44.51% to

data.full_content:
Today 16:00
RNS Number : 8382P
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
21 January 2026
THE INFORMATION CONTAINED WITHIN THIS ANNOUNCEMENT IS DEEMED BY THE COMPANY TO CONSTITUTE INSIDE INFORMATION AS STIPULATED UNDER THE MARKET ABUSE REGULATION (EU) NO. 596/2014, AS AMENDED WHICH, BY VIRTUE OF THE EUROPEAN UNION (WITHDRAWAL) ACT 2018, FORMS PART OF UK LAW. ON THE PUBLICATION OF THIS ANNOUNCEMENT VIA A REGULATORY INFORMATION SERVICE ("RIS"), THIS INSIDE INFORMATION IS NOW CONSIDERED TO BE IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN.
SEALAND CAPITAL GALAXY LIMITED
("Sealand"
or the
"Company")
Director Appointment and CFO Appointment
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL), is pleased to announce the appointment of Mr Sunny Terng to the Board as an Independent Non-Executive Director, with immediate effect. The Company further announces that it has appointed Mr Peng Liu (Patrick) as Chief Financial Officer, with immediate effect.
Chong Sun Terng - Independent Non-Executive Director, Audit Committee Chair
Mr. Chong Sun Terng (aged 35) is a finance and investment banking professional with over 10 years' experience across audit, advisory and capital markets, with a focus on cross-border transactions and capital raising. His experience spans China, Hong Kong, Malaysia and the UK, covering M&A, strategic investment execution, IPO advisory and financial and compliance advisory.
Mr. Terng is currently Executive Director, Investment Banking at Fernwin Capital (Shenzhen) Co., Ltd. (April 2023 to present), working on cross-border M&A and capital raising transactions, strategic investments in NASDAQ listed companies and IPO advisory assignments.
Previously, he worked at GreenPro Capital Corp (Hong Kong) (Nasdaq: GRNQ) (January 2022 to March 2023) in a financial advisory and audit capacity. Earlier in his career, Mr. Terng was Audit Manager at Kaizen CPA Limited (Hong Kong) (July 2019 to December 2021) and worked in audit in Malaysia.
The Company expects that Mr. Terng will serve as Chair of the Audit Committee.
In addition to his appointment at Sealand, Mr. Terng currently holds, or has held during the past five years, the following directorships:
Current directorships / partnerships
·
Executive Director - Fernwin Capital (Shenzen) Co., Ltd
Past directorships / partnerships (last five years)
·
None.
There is nothing further to disclose under LR 9.6.13R.
Peng Liu - Chief Financial Officer
Mr. Peng Liu (aged 33) is an experienced finance professional with a background spanning auditing, financial management and IPO advisory. He has worked on a range of audit and corporate finance assignments, including due diligence, equity investment support, M&A advisory work, internal control reviews and IPO planning, including cross-border listing and financing projects.
Mr. Liu is currently Vice President (IBD) at Shiyida Enterprise Management Consulting (Shenzhen) Co., Ltd. (October 2024 to present), where he oversees domestic and overseas listing and financing projects, including project screening and evaluation, due diligence, overseas IPO planning, compliance initiatives, pre-IPO financing, restructuring and financial advisory work, including designing and implementing red-chip structures.
Prior to this, he was Associate Manager at Dahua Certified Public Accountants (Shenzhen) (February 2023 to October 2024), leading audit and advisory projects including annual audits, internal control audits and risk and compliance testing. He previously worked as an Auditor at Shinewing Certified Public Accountants (Shenzhen) (October 2021 to February 2023).
Mr. Liu holds an MSc in Accounting and Finance from the University of Leeds (UK) and a BSc in Accounting from the University of Tulsa (USA). He is fluent in English and Chinese and has experience across IFRS, US GAAP and Chinese Accounting Standards (CAS).
Dr Thomas Sawyer, CEO of Sealand, commented:
"I am delighted to welcome Mr. Terng to the Board and to appoint Mr. Liu as our Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Terng brings valuable cross-border capital markets and audit experience that will strengthen our governance, particularly through his chairing of the Audit Committee. Mr. Liu's financial management and IPO advisory expertise will enhance our finance function as we continue to execute our strategy."
-Ends-

data.author: crober33
data.content: A few comments suggesting this RNS is “bad news”, “extra wages” or proof that nothing is coming don’t really stand up to scrutiny. First point: Companies do not appoint a CFO with IPO, M&A and cross-border capital markets experience if nothing is happening. If a business was drifting or failing, you cut costs and keep things quiet — you don’t strengthen governance and finance capability. Second: This isn’t “just another director”. This is: • A CFO with listing, restructuring and financing experience • A NED/Audit Chair with capital markets and deal execution background • Strong Asia-facing credentials, which aligns with SCGL’s stated strategy That’s preparation, not panic. Third: The idea that appointments mean “no news coming” is backwards. In practice, serious companies get the structure in place before releasing material updates, especially when dealing with funding, partnerships or corporate actions. You don’t announce first and tidy up later. Fourth: At ~£4.5–£5m market cap, the downside case is already priced in. The market is valuing SCGL as if nothing will ever happen again. Any credible progress — commercial, strategic or transactional — completely breaks that assumption. Finally: Price action matters. Despite all the noise: • The stock is holding well above the pre-move lows • Large volumes have been absorbed • There is no collapse despite constant negativity That tells you supply is drying up and weak hands have largely gone. No one is claiming instant riches or guaranteed outcomes. But dismissing this RNS as meaningless ignores what companies actually do when they are positioning for the next phase. IMO this strengthens the medium-term case, not weakens it — and at these levels the risk/reward remains skewed to the upside. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: crober33
data.content: Just thinking out loud here, but the pieces starting to come together are interesting. EVOO AI is already a standalone vehicle (EVOO AI PLC), and the recent board/CFO appointments at Sealand Capital Galaxy Ltd add skills you don’t usually bring in unless you’re thinking beyond day-to-day AIM admin. Both new appointments have backgrounds in: • cross-border M&A • capital markets and IPO advisory • US GAAP / IFRS / structuring • Asia ↔ US transactions That’s exactly the toolkit you’d need for a reverse merger into a US-listed shell, which is how many early-stage AI and tech companies access Nasdaq without a traditional IPO. Important to say: – I’m not saying this is confirmed – I’m not saying it’s imminent – And it wouldn’t be SCGL listing on Nasdaq anyway The logical route would be EVOO AI rolling out fully, proving traction, then using a reverse takeover of a US vehicle to accelerate access to US capital and visibility. That’s a well-trodden path for AI stories. If EVOO AI delivers on execution, a US listing (via reverse merger rather than IPO) becomes plausible, not fantasy. And any move like that would obviously have a major knock-on effect for SCGL’s valuation through its stake. Speculative, yes — but the direction of travel and recent appointments fit that narrative far better than the “nothing is happening” argument. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: crober33
data.content: Senior finance professionals don’t join companies lightly. They do due diligence, they look at cash position, strategy and pipeline, and they assess personal reputational risk. You don’t step into a CFO or Audit Chair role if a business is drifting or about to fail. On the CEO point, if there really was “nothing happening”, the last thing you’d expect to see is: strengthened governance a proper CFO appointment an experienced Audit Committee Chair That’s normally what you do before execution, not after failure.

data.author: kentan
data.content: Crober 33, big flaw in your argument ... SCGL is listed on the full market, not AIM. In 2025 it was a star performer in the P&D returns. ... I was in early  and showing a big loss because of its listing, (that drew me to it), but that soon turned to profit when the herd arrived and propelled it into the star "share of the decade" ... I then took a huge profit and prophesied a return to the doldrums because it hadn't shown any profits or increased prospects of getting the EVOO platform off of the ground .... that still remains the same, nothing significant has changed. data.author: crober33
data.content: Fair post and I get where you’re coming from, especially given you’ve traded this successfully before. But I think there are a couple of important distinctions this time that are being overlooked. First, agreed – SCGL is not AIM, and that actually raises the bar on governance and disclosure. That’s precisely why the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments matter more than previous board changes. These aren’t promotional NEDs; they’re finance, audit and capital-markets specialists. That’s a different class of appointment. Second, while it’s true that EVOO hasn’t yet delivered meaningful revenue, it’s not accurate to say nothing has changed. We now have: a published prospectus strengthened finance and audit functions clear Asia / cross-border capital markets focus and a board being shaped for execution, not survival Those are prerequisites for monetisation or corporate action. You don’t usually see them after profits arrive — they come before. Third, the “P&D only” argument doesn’t fully explain why experienced professionals would now attach their names and reputations if this was just another dead cat. They don’t need SCGL; SCGL needs them. That imbalance is telling. Totally fair to wait for revenues — that’s a disciplined approach. But for some of us, the opportunity is in the transition phase, before profits are obvious and the market has repriced it. Not saying this is guaranteed or risk-free — far from it — but I do think this setup is meaningfully different from the previous false dawns. DYOR and GLA.

data.author: crober33
data.content: Lots of sensible points being raised here, but when you step back and join the dots, the picture looks far more positive than some are suggesting. Yes, volatility is high — but that’s exactly what you get when a stock has: • a tiny free float • a £4–5m market cap • renewed attention after months of dormancy. Wild swings don’t mean weakness; they mean scarcity + demand colliding. On cash levels: The September interims clearly state sufficient working capital for at least 12 months taking into account the CLNs. That’s not unusual for growth-stage companies, and importantly, it removes the “immediate cliff-edge” risk that some are implying. Funding discussions, if any, are far more likely to be strategic, not emergency. On “false dawns” and missed timelines: Fair comment historically — but companies don’t suddenly appoint: • a CFO with IPO, restructuring and cross-border financing experience • an Audit Chair with M&A and Nasdaq-facing capital markets background …unless they believe execution is moving closer. This is not promotional fluff; this is infrastructure being put in place. The Fernwin Capital connection is particularly interesting. That firm has been directly involved in Asian tech investments that later ended up in Nasdaq-listed exits. That doesn’t guarantee anything here — but it absolutely destroys the idea that these are random or meaningless appointments. On “speculation vs delivery”: Everyone agrees delivery matters. But markets price transitions, not finished products. By the time revenues are obvious and profits flowing, this won’t be a sub-£5m valuation. That’s the risk/reward trade-off: • Wait for certainty and pay a much higher price • Or accept speculation at depressed levels Neither approach is wrong — but dismissing this as “nothing has changed” simply isn’t accurate. Finally, price action matters: Despite all the negativity, the stock is holding well above the pre-move lows, with demand reappearing quickly on dips. That tells you sentiment has shifted, even if conviction is still building. For me, this looks like a company moving from talk → structure → execution. Still speculative, yes — but the foundations being laid now are exactly what you’d expect before something more meaningful lands, not after. GLA to all, whatever your strategy. DYOR 🦜 🚢 🪙

data.author: crober33
data.content: Putting the emotion aside, the setup for a 1p move is actually straightforward. • The speeding ticket did its job – weak hands flushed, sentiment reset • Price did not collapse after it, instead it based in the mid-0.4s • Large sells have been absorbed, not dumped through • Spread has tightened again – a sign MMs aren’t in panic mode At ~0.45–0.50p the market cap is under £5m. That’s tiny. It doesn’t take heroic buying to re-rate this to £10m, which is 1p. That’s a doubling, not a fantasy valuation. Importantly: Most long-term holders are not selling at these levels Supply dries up quickly once buyers step aside We’ve already seen how fast this moves when momentum returns The stock was 0.85p before the RNS, and nothing fundamental has changed since then. If anything, the register is now cleaner and expectations are lower – which is exactly when AIM stocks tend to make their next leg. This doesn’t need “13p talk” or miracle news. It just needs: ✔ continued absorption ✔ a reclaim of 0.55–0.60 ✔ momentum to do what it always does on AIM From there, 1p becomes a very realistic magnet, not a stretch target. DYOR, manage risk, but dismissing 1p from a £5m market cap stock that’s already shown it can move fast feels overly pessimistic.

data.content: ✝️ Revd OldSharedog’s Sunday Sermon — SCGL Edition “On the Mysteries of the Mediterranean Flapjack” Beloved shareholders, gather close, for today we reflect upon one of the great unanswered questions of our age: What, in the name of Sealand, is actually in the Mediterranean Flapjack? For lo, the kitchen is overseen by Colenal, a man whose culinary leadership is so experimental that even the ingredients file has filed for witness protection. He stirs, he mixes, he mutters ancient recipes last seen on a Mykonos ferry menu, and yet somehow the flapjack emerges each week with a new flavour profile and a fresh sense of existential dread. And then, my children, we turn to Tiger, the PR maestro — or rather, the PR misadventure. For truly, if communication were flapjack, Tiger would forget the oats, burn the tray, and then issue a press release saying everything was “progressing well”. Thus the mystery deepens. Is the Mediterranean Flapjack a product? A concept? A hallucination brought on by too many late‑night RNS refreshes? Only Colenal knows, and Tiger certainly isn’t telling us. Yet the faithful remain hopeful, for in the Book of SCGL it is written: “Blessed are those who wait, for eventually even Tiger must say something useful.” Go forth in patience, humour, and mild confusion. Amen. DOG BLESS YOU ALL - WHERE'S THE DOT !!!

data.author: crober33
data.content: A few comments suggesting this RNS is “bad news”, “extra wages” or proof that nothing is coming don’t really stand up to scrutiny. First point: Companies do not appoint a CFO with IPO, M&A and cross-border capital markets experience if nothing is happening. If a business was drifting or failing, you cut costs and keep things quiet — you don’t strengthen governance and finance capability. Second: This isn’t “just another director”. This is: • A CFO with listing, restructuring and financing experience • A NED/Audit Chair with capital markets and deal execution background • Strong Asia-facing credentials, which aligns with SCGL’s stated strategy That’s preparation, not panic. Third: The idea that appointments mean “no news coming” is backwards. In practice, serious companies get the structure in place before releasing material updates, especially when dealing with funding, partnerships or corporate actions. You don’t announce first and tidy up later. Fourth: At ~£4.5–£5m market cap, the downside case is already priced in. The market is valuing SCGL as if nothing will ever happen again. Any credible progress — commercial, strategic or transactional — completely breaks that assumption. Finally: Price action matters. Despite all the noise: • The stock is holding well above the pre-move lows • Large volumes have been absorbed • There is no collapse despite constant negativity That tells you supply is drying up and weak hands have largely gone. No one is claiming instant riches or guaranteed outcomes. But dismissing this RNS as meaningless ignores what companies actually do when they are positioning for the next phase. IMO this strengthens the medium-term case, not weakens it — and at these levels the risk/reward remains skewed to the upside. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: crober33
data.content: Just thinking out loud here, but the pieces starting to come together are interesting. EVOO AI is already a standalone vehicle (EVOO AI PLC), and the recent board/CFO appointments at Sealand Capital Galaxy Ltd add skills you don’t usually bring in unless you’re thinking beyond day-to-day AIM admin. Both new appointments have backgrounds in: • cross-border M&A • capital markets and IPO advisory • US GAAP / IFRS / structuring • Asia ↔ US transactions That’s exactly the toolkit you’d need for a reverse merger into a US-listed shell, which is how many early-stage AI and tech companies access Nasdaq without a traditional IPO. Important to say: – I’m not saying this is confirmed – I’m not saying it’s imminent – And it wouldn’t be SCGL listing on Nasdaq anyway The logical route would be EVOO AI rolling out fully, proving traction, then using a reverse takeover of a US vehicle to accelerate access to US capital and visibility. That’s a well-trodden path for AI stories. If EVOO AI delivers on execution, a US listing (via reverse merger rather than IPO) becomes plausible, not fantasy. And any move like that would obviously have a major knock-on effect for SCGL’s valuation through its stake. Speculative, yes — but the direction of travel and recent appointments fit that narrative far better than the “nothing is happening” argument. DYOR. GLA.

data.content: Senior finance professionals don’t join companies lightly. They do due diligence, they look at cash position, strategy and pipeline, and they assess personal reputational risk. You don’t step into a CFO or Audit Chair role if a business is drifting or about to fail. On the CEO point, if there really was “nothing happening”, the last thing you’d expect to see is: strengthened governance a proper CFO appointment an experienced Audit Committee Chair That’s normally what you do before execution, not after failure.

data.author: crober33
data.content: Fair post and I get where you’re coming from, especially given you’ve traded this successfully before. But I think there are a couple of important distinctions this time that are being overlooked. First, agreed – SCGL is not AIM, and that actually raises the bar on governance and disclosure. That’s precisely why the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments matter more than previous board changes. These aren’t promotional NEDs; they’re finance, audit and capital-markets specialists. That’s a different class of appointment. Second, while it’s true that EVOO hasn’t yet delivered meaningful revenue, it’s not accurate to say nothing has changed. We now have: a published prospectus strengthened finance and audit functions clear Asia / cross-border capital markets focus and a board being shaped for execution, not survival Those are prerequisites for monetisation or corporate action. You don’t usually see them after profits arrive — they come before. Third, the “P&D only” argument doesn’t fully explain why experienced professionals would now attach their names and reputations if this was just another dead cat. They don’t need SCGL; SCGL needs them. That imbalance is telling. Totally fair to wait for revenues — that’s a disciplined approach. But for some of us, the opportunity is in the transition phase, before profits are obvious and the market has repriced it. Not saying this is guaranteed or risk-free — far from it — but I do think this setup is meaningfully different from the previous false dawns. DYOR and GLA.

data.author: crober33
data.content: Putting the emotion aside, the setup for a 1p move is actually straightforward. • The speeding ticket did its job – weak hands flushed, sentiment reset • Price did not collapse after it, instead it based in the mid-0.4s • Large sells have been absorbed, not dumped through • Spread has tightened again – a sign MMs aren’t in panic mode At ~0.45–0.50p the market cap is under £5m. That’s tiny. It doesn’t take heroic buying to re-rate this to £10m, which is 1p. That’s a doubling, not a fantasy valuation. Importantly: Most long-term holders are not selling at these levels Supply dries up quickly once buyers step aside We’ve already seen how fast this moves when momentum returns The stock was 0.85p before the RNS, and nothing fundamental has changed since then. If anything, the register is now cleaner and expectations are lower – which is exactly when AIM stocks tend to make their next leg. This doesn’t need “13p talk” or miracle news. It just needs: ✔ continued absorption ✔ a reclaim of 0.55–0.60 ✔ momentum to do what it always does on AIM From there, 1p becomes a very realistic magnet, not a stretch target. DYOR, manage risk, but dismissing 1p from a £5m market cap stock that’s already shown it can move fast feels overly pessimistic.

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: ✝️ Revd OldSharedog’s Sunday Sermon — SCGL Edition “On the Mysteries of the Mediterranean Flapjack” Beloved shareholders, gather close, for today we reflect upon one of the great unanswered questions of our age: What, in the name of Sealand, is actually in the Mediterranean Flapjack? For lo, the kitchen is overseen by Colenal, a man whose culinary leadership is so experimental that even the ingredients file has filed for witness protection. He stirs, he mixes, he mutters ancient recipes last seen on a Mykonos ferry menu, and yet somehow the flapjack emerges each week with a new flavour profile and a fresh sense of existential dread. And then, my children, we turn to Tiger, the PR maestro — or rather, the PR misadventure. For truly, if communication were flapjack, Tiger would forget the oats, burn the tray, and then issue a press release saying everything was “progressing well”. Thus the mystery deepens. Is the Mediterranean Flapjack a product? A concept? A hallucination brought on by too many late‑night RNS refreshes? Only Colenal knows, and Tiger certainly isn’t telling us. Yet the faithful remain hopeful, for in the Book of SCGL it is written: “Blessed are those who wait, for eventually even Tiger must say something useful.” Go forth in patience, humour, and mild confusion. Amen. DOG BLESS YOU ALL - WHERE'S THE DOT !!!

data.title: Strategic Update and Business Expansion
data.full_content:
27 Jan 2026 16:00
RNS Number : 6002Q
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
27 January 2026
THE INFORMATION CONTAINED WITHIN THIS ANNOUNCEMENT IS DEEMED BY THE COMPANY TO CONSTITUTE INSIDE INFORMATION AS STIPULATED UNDER THE MARKET ABUSE REGULATION (EU) NO. 596/2014, AS AMENDED WHICH, BY VIRTUE OF THE EUROPEAN UNION (WITHDRAWAL) ACT 2018, FORMS PART OF UK LAW. ON THE PUBLICATION OF THIS ANNOUNCEMENT VIA A REGULATORY INFORMATION SERVICE ("RIS"), THIS INSIDE INFORMATION IS NOW CONSIDERED TO BE IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN.
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
("Sealand" or the "Company")
Strategic
Update
and Business Expansion
The Board of Sealand (LSE: SCGL) is pleased to announce its intention to
enhance
the Company's strategic objectives and core business operations. The Board believes that focusing the Company's resources on high-growth technology and AI-led opportunities is the best route to enhance long-term shareholder value. Following a review of market trends and the Company's capabilities, the Board intends to
upgrade
and augment the Company's developmental priorities (the "Expansion").
Strategic focus: technology and AI
Under the intended Expansion, the Company plans to prioritise:
·
AI and SaaS software tools to support commercial deployment of digital management solutions; and
·
Computing-power infrastructure and energy technology, with the aim of building a more integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance.
The Board believes this renewed focus will strengthen the Company's competitiveness and support sustainable revenue generation over time.
Geographic focus: Asia-Pacific
The Company intends to prioritise the Asia-Pacific region through a dual-hub approach:
·
Shenzhen as the hub for Mainland China operations (Greater Bay Area); and
·
Hong Kong as a base for expansion into Southeast Asia and broader Asian markets.
Supporting activities
To support the execution of the Expansion, the Company aims to:
·
provide advisory services to international companies entering China and the UK market; and
·
pursue selective investments aligned with the Company's technology and AI strategy where the Board considers these accelerate delivery of the intended priorities.
Governance and implementation
The Board intends to ensure it has an appropriate mix of skills and experience to oversee the Company's intended technological and infrastructure priorities and may evaluate synergistic M&A opportunities consistent with the Expansion.
All actions will be undertaken in accordance with applicable UK regulatory requirements, including the UK Listing Rules and the Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules. The Company will provide further updates as appropriate.
For the avoidance of doubt, this announcement sets out the Company's intended strategic direction only and does not constitute a profit forecast or investment commitment.
The Directors of the Company are responsible for the release of this announcement.
Enquiries:
Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited
Dr. Thomas Sawyer (Chief Executive Officer)
Mr. Siqi Cao (Executive Director)
Bowsprit Partners Limited (Financial Adviser)
+44 (0) 203 833 4430
Stockbox Media (PR/IR)
info@stockboxmedia.com
Notes to Editors:
The Company's Shares are traded on the Equity Shares (Transition) category of the London Stock Exchange under ticker LSE: SCGL.
Further information on Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited is available on:
www.sealandcapitalgalaxy.com
This information is provided by RNS, the news service of the London Stock Exchange. RNS is approved by the Financial Conduct Authority to act as a Primary Information Provider in the United Kingdom. or visit

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Spot on, Colenal. Everything you’ve said hits the mark. No one here is “marrying” this share — it’s a small outsider punt, for most - nothing more, and treating it that way is the only sane approach given the lack of substance over the past year. I now have a more realistic holding here - far from where i was this time last year !!! Although I have all but written off ( mentally ) the investment, and will be delighted if my investment was returned. Fortunately it doesn't impact my overall investments in others - so that at least is a bonus. You’re absolutely right about the difference between negativity and realism. If the old circus rolled back in and pumped this to silly levels again, half the board would be cheering them on while sprinting for the exit. The fact most holders would happily sell on even a modest rise tells you exactly how fragile the confidence really is. Your take on charts is bang on too. They show history, not destiny. Great for quick trades if you’re nimble, but for small players it’s just another gamble — like backing a horse after six wins and expecting value. And until an RNS is backed by something meaningful — not pocket‑change revenue or vague promises — this is likely to keep drifting exactly as it has. That’s not being negative, that’s just calling the race as it’s running. Solid post, well put. OSD - Still trying to get the lister running smoothly - its like 10 little drummer boys at the moment - not the purring beauty i envisaged !!

data.author: Colenal
data.content: Lots of interesting points to take from those comments. With regard to marrying a share, that is a term I have read many times, some might, but I  am definitely not doing that here, I treat it as an outsider in the Grand National and if it sinks it is a small loss, but I wouldn't personally put a pound on it now. In my opinion there is a big difference between talking a share down in a negative manner and a healthy dose of realism, I don't feel we can bite both ends of the biscuit, not many would complain if the band of clowns returned and talked this up to a level that gave them multiples of their investment back. Most have forgotten what has taken this up in the past year, the answer is very little, and most would rush for the door on a rise a little higher than earlier this month, which says to me that they have little more faith than Kentan or myself, the only difference being that he isn't in this and we are. When it comes to charts, I said before, I have little understanding, but the one thing I have noticed is exactly what has just been said, they give information on what has happened, not what will happen, I can see that you can use them for a quick 10% but they wouldn't work for a small player like me, you don't get the best price on a horse that has just had 6 straight wins, stuff like this is just a gamble. As always the amateur is sorry to anyone I have offended but until something that is announced in an R.N.S. is actually backed up by something meaningful rather than accounts saying that the revenue paid the milkman then I think this is going to keep doing exactly what it has done for the last 12 months.

data.author: crober33
data.content: First off – no one sensible is “marrying” this share. That phrase gets thrown around whenever price pulls back, but risk management cuts both ways. Ignoring a setup because of past failures can be just as costly as blind faith. On charts (for Musk / chartists): Yes, the trend was down. Everyone can see that. But charts don’t predict news – they react to it. What changed recently isn’t price action, it’s structure: • New CFO and Audit Chair with cross-border M&A / IPO backgrounds • Formal strategic pivot into AI, SaaS, compute + energy infrastructure • Explicit wording around synergistic M&A and platform building • Asia-Pac focus with HK + Shenzhen hubs That’s not noise. That’s a corporate reset. Charts lag fundamentals at inflection points – and SCGL has form for violent re-ratings once sentiment flips (people seem to forget 0.07 → 1.3p didn’t come from “good charts”). On EVOO / “no mention = dead”: Silence ≠ cancellation. If anything, this RNS broadens the scope beyond one JV. Companies don’t narrow vision when something collapses – they do it when they’re building optionality. EVOO can still sit inside a wider AI / compute platform rather than being the headline On “AI bubble bursting”: The bubble isn’t AI – it’s unrevenue AI. Compute, infrastructure, energy assurance and SaaS tooling are exactly where real money is flowing. That’s what this RNS points toward.

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: Given the BODs need for issuing previous speeding tickets, I can't help feeling like they want to issue information piecemeal. Just reviewing the specific wording and with a bit of use of AI myself, this is wat it tells me. "Dual-Hub" Strategy for Greater Bay Area: Chinese-language coverage and regional business outlets are highlighting the formalization of a Shenzhen hub for Mainland China operations and a Hong Kong hub for Southeast Asian expansion. This positioning is intended to leverage Shenzhen's tech manufacturing power for the new "computing infrastructure" push. Infrastructure & Energy Assurance: Rather than just a luxury app, the press notes that the project is now building out computing-power infrastructure and energy technology. This aligns with broader Chinese national strategies to integrate AI into energy systems to support high-intensity processing. Expansion into B2B SaaS: The latest reports indicate that SEA-VOO is moving beyond direct-to-consumer luxury retail to offer AI-driven SaaS digital management tools for businesses. My own concern from this is that if there is a desire to build datacentres they will oodles of cash, that won't com from a raise though, more likely a JV I'd say

data.author: callit
data.content: After a little bit of digging this bit of the RNS stands out to me: "Computing-power infrastructure and energy technology, with the aim of building a more integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance." It seems that after the US bans on exporting NVIDIA GPU's and then backtracking, China has now started restricting them themselves. https://scanx.trade/stock-market-news/global/nvidia-ceo-jensen-huang-visits-china-as-h200-chips-face-customs-restrictions/30787877 It got me thinking, what if someone were to build datacenters of NVIDIA GPU's just outside the China border and then supply computing into China? Then I thought could this be done from Hong Kong, Is Hong King subject to the same restrictions? So I asked GPT. Take this wit a pinch of salt as it's often wrong but, this was the result: "NVIDIA GPU Restrictions and Hong Kong Current Status of Restrictions The restrictions placed on the import of NVIDIA GPUs and advanced semiconductors primarily target mainland China. Hong Kong, operating under a separate customs regime, generally enjoys more lenient access to technology and components. This means: Import Controls: The stringent export controls and restrictions imposed by the U.S. on semiconductor technology largely do not apply to Hong Kong in the same way they do to mainland China. Procurement Flexibility: Companies in Hong Kong often have greater flexibility to import high-tech components, including NVIDIA GPUs, compared to those in mainland China. Regulatory Framework: Hong Kong has its own regulatory system, which differs from that of mainland China, making it easier for companies to access new technologies. Limitations and Considerations While Hong Kong has significant advantages regarding access to NVIDIA GPUs, businesses must be mindful of: Evolving Geopolitical Landscape: As international dynamics shift, potential policy changes could impact access in the future. Compliance Requirements: Companies must ensure compliance with both local laws and relevant international regulations, even in Hong Kong. Conclusion Currently, Hong Kong is not subject to the same restrictions on the import of NVIDIA GPUs as applies to mainland China, making it a strategic location for establishing data centers to meet the demand for advanced computing resources. Would you like more information on logistic considerations or any other specific aspect?" It struck me in he article that the large Chinese AI companies would like to get access to NVIDIA GPU`s include our old friend Tencent(See previous RNS's about JV with Tencent subsidiary). Of course we also have links to NVIDIA through their connect programme. Seems we could be in the sweet spot. Anyway all putting 2 + 2 together and getting 5 and who knows if GPT speaks with forked tongue. Certainly interesting times ahead. GLA DYOR

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: The latest announcements from Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) directly align with the SEA-VOO AI ASIA initiative by transitioning it from a conceptual partnership into an active, operational phase. In short, the recent updates move SEA-VOO from a "strategic vision" to a technically-backed, well-funded project with a clear path to market through established engineering partners. Key points of alignment include: Platform Development: Sealand selected Vacuumlabs as the strategic development partner for the SEA-VOO rollout. Vacuumlabs will build the technical infrastructure to integrate EVOO's AI with Sealand’s payment and distribution systems. Expansion of AI Scope: While SEA-VOO was originally focused on a "best-in-class luxury commerce experience", the latest updates expand this to include AI-driven SaaS digital management tools. This allows Sealand to offer business-to-business (B2B) services alongside its consumer-facing e-commerce platform. Infrastructure & Technical Validation: The alignment is further strengthened by EVOO AI’s acceptance into the NVIDIA Connect Program. This provides SEA-VOO with advanced AI tools and reduced computing costs, accelerating the roadmap for AI-powered personalization in the luxury market. Operational "Dual-Hub" Strategy: Sealand’s move to establish hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong provides the physical and legal framework needed for SEA-VOO to target the broader APAC market while maintaining exclusive rights to EVOO’s Olive technology in the region. Leadership for Scaling: Recent appointments, including a new CFO and Independent Non-Executive Director with cross-border transaction expertise, are designed to oversee the financial and strategic scaling of the SEA-VOO venture.

data.author: crober33
data.content: This RNS shouldn’t be dismissed as “just words” — it actually ties together everything we’ve seen recently. For the first time, SCGL has formally locked in: • AI + SaaS as the core focus • computing power + energy infrastructure • Asia-Pacific as the execution base • and explicit consideration of synergistic M&A That explains the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments perfectly. You don’t bring in IPO, cross-border M&A and capital-markets specialists unless you’re planning something more ambitious than business-as-usual. The mention of: “integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance” …is a huge step up from a single-project narrative. This positions SCGL as a platform vehicle, not a punt on one app. At a ~£4m market cap, the market is still valuing SCGL as if none of this matters. But companies don’t publish a prospectus, restructure their board, pivot strategy and openly flag M&A unless they believe execution is coming. This feels like the groundwork phase before something more concrete — whether that’s asset injection, partnership, funding or corporate action. Still speculative? Yes. But dismissing this as meaningless now looks increasingly wrong. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Colenal - something you may be interested in - We have walked up the hill this morning to Kefalos Village. I am going to help grind some wheat & other stuff for Nic & his family to produce flour for their restaurant and neighbouring bakeries. They only grind once or twice a month and it has become quite a local treat - filling their coffers with all the coffee and cake they sell !! It is the last working windmill on Kos and is so interesting - especially being involved - usually lugging bags down the cave walks to the storage area. You can find the details if you go on Google earth and put in either Mylotopi restaurant or windmill. The view from up here is fabulous. And just a thought why I have posted this - it is an example of a business literally turning fresh air into a valuable asset :) May SCGL learn how to do that - it would be wonderful !! OSD - hoping to get a free slice of cake :)

data.author: callit
data.content: Colenal, you are entitled to take a cautious approach if you see fit, but that analogy doesn`t match what we have here. More like they borrowed £10 and said they would pay it back in a year, 10 months later they say hello to you but don't mention the money. They don't ask for any further money, and now you wonder will I get the £10 in a few months as promised. They haven't defaulted on the debt. If you borrowed that money from a bank you wouldn't expect them to send the debt collectors until the debt was actually not paid within agreed time limits. You wouldn't expect them to have repossessed your car before the debt was up and then said it was because you didn't contact them to say you were still going to pay what was owed. It's the act of defaulting on the act of defaulting on the debt that is important, it matters not if there is communication on some other topic and no mention of the debt. If it's not in default it's not in default. The 'Summer' date is something people got from EVOO's website. It's nothing to do with Sealand or SEAVOO, though there may be a requirement for SEAVOO to use technology developed by EVOO and a delay of EVOO may make some doubt a bit more how that technology is progressing. SUMMER launch was never RNS'd for SEAVOO. Expected news in the 4th quarter, which will be in alignment with the financial year not the calendar year I would assume. GLA DYOR

data.author: Colenal
data.content: To what extent ? A slightly higher extent than we should consider it to have gone well. If you lent someone £10 a year ago on the promise it would be repaid the next day and they disappeared until last week asking for another  £10 loan promising to repay it the next day you wouldn't believe them. I am happy  to believe that we might get get lucky here if and when the day-trippers return and pump it a bit higher than their last effort, but to get excited about that R.N.S. that talked much and said little is not for me, and I know I am not alone in thinking that way. I am fully aware that we are gambling and like everyone else I don't care what takes the S.P. up but this horse is the rank outsider in the race and all the ifs, mights or coulds will not change that no matter how much we try to talk it up. Again recently the talk has turned to sellers being finished, and MMs playing games to let their friends in. If we go back 6 months the S.P. was at a similar level and the posts were exactly the same 'MMs playing games',  'they will have to let this go soon',  'letting their friends in cheap' ,  none of those posters have been right yet but if this goes near .5 they will all scream 'this it, 1p before close.' We may get rich here but don't hold your breath. All I am saying is live in the real world.

data.author: callit
data.content: Response from AI: "Proportion of Software Projects Launched Late Approximately 90% of software projects face delays beyond their initially stated release dates. This statistic highlights the significant challenges within software development, with many factors contributing to these delays. Key Factors Contributing to Delays Late Stage Design Changes: A predominant reason cited for delays is modifications made during late stages of development, which can often be within the control of the engineering teams. Poor Estimation and Planning: Many projects suffer from inaccurate estimations regarding the time and resources needed for completion, leading to overruns. Resource Allocation Issues: Shortages in key components or issues with international shipping can also impact timelines. Breakdown of Project Success Rates Only 31% of software projects are completed on time and within budget. Around 52% are considered "challenged," meaning they either run over budget or miss deadlines but are still launched. 19% are outright failures, meaning they are abandoned entirely before launch. Conclusion The high percentage of delayed software releases points to a systemic issue in project management and estimation. Understanding these factors can help organizations improve their planning and potentially reduce the incidence of delays in future projects." So the real questions is, if 90% of software projects are launched late, to what extent should we consider delays in the launch of SEAVOO to mean it all went belly up? GLA DYOR

data.author: crober33
data.content: Worth remembering the Vacuumlabs RNS (strategic development partner) only landed late Feb 2025. That’s effectively when the build clock started. For an AI-enabled platform of this scope, a realistic timeline is: 6–9 months for an MVP / pilot 9–15 months for something commercially usable That puts the earliest meaningful outcomes Q4 2025, with more realistic progress updates Q1–Q2 2026 — especially given the broader AI/SaaS strategy now outlined. So delays ≠ nothing happening. Partner selected usually means work begins, not launch next month. Next sensible updates to look for would be: pilot / controlled rollout commercial partnerships revenue-linked milestones DYOR. GLA.

data.content: The beauty of charting is that it shows you market structure ,for investors like many here ,at first that need to know what is price doing ,not what you want it to do ,eliminating your own biases and understanding objectively ,so u look at the chart over a higher timeframe ,up ,down or sideways ,only 3 direction price can move .secondly ,using historical point of consideration poc,evaluate ,where the poss are that the likelyhood of price reaction snr ,support and resistance ,volume comes to play at thos areas you have the first indication ,with other indicators one can evaluate at where you want to enter and where you want to exit ,chart is not a crystal ball,its a way of evaluating probabilities ,and where the bias will be on your side ,with strict stop loss in place .it should be mechanical in disciplined ,...so here which way is price travelling 2.what is strength of the price rsi  3 MA 50 and 200,many use others ,but over time i use only 3 volume and rsi ,MA ,keeping the chart as clean as possible for simplicity ..if price is goin down i dont want to take part .knowing when to particpate can only come from charts ,not to enter or exit blindly https://invst.ly/1f134p

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Spot on, Colenal. Everything you’ve said hits the mark. No one here is “marrying” this share — it’s a small outsider punt, for most - nothing more, and treating it that way is the only sane approach given the lack of substance over the past year. I now have a more realistic holding here - far from where i was this time last year !!! Although I have all but written off ( mentally ) the investment, and will be delighted if my investment was returned. Fortunately it doesn't impact my overall investments in others - so that at least is a bonus. You’re absolutely right about the difference between negativity and realism. If the old circus rolled back in and pumped this to silly levels again, half the board would be cheering them on while sprinting for the exit. The fact most holders would happily sell on even a modest rise tells you exactly how fragile the confidence really is. Your take on charts is bang on too. They show history, not destiny. Great for quick trades if you’re nimble, but for small players it’s just another gamble — like backing a horse after six wins and expecting value. And until an RNS is backed by something meaningful — not pocket‑change revenue or vague promises — this is likely to keep drifting exactly as it has. That’s not being negative, that’s just calling the race as it’s running. Solid post, well put. OSD - Still trying to get the lister running smoothly - its like 10 little drummer boys at the moment - not the purring beauty i envisaged !!

data.author: Colenal
data.content: Lots of interesting points to take from those comments. With regard to marrying a share, that is a term I have read many times, some might, but I  am definitely not doing that here, I treat it as an outsider in the Grand National and if it sinks it is a small loss, but I wouldn't personally put a pound on it now. In my opinion there is a big difference between talking a share down in a negative manner and a healthy dose of realism, I don't feel we can bite both ends of the biscuit, not many would complain if the band of clowns returned and talked this up to a level that gave them multiples of their investment back. Most have forgotten what has taken this up in the past year, the answer is very little, and most would rush for the door on a rise a little higher than earlier this month, which says to me that they have little more faith than Kentan or myself, the only difference being that he isn't in this and we are. When it comes to charts, I said before, I have little understanding, but the one thing I have noticed is exactly what has just been said, they give information on what has happened, not what will happen, I can see that you can use them for a quick 10% but they wouldn't work for a small player like me, you don't get the best price on a horse that has just had 6 straight wins, stuff like this is just a gamble. As always the amateur is sorry to anyone I have offended but until something that is announced in an R.N.S. is actually backed up by something meaningful rather than accounts saying that the revenue paid the milkman then I think this is going to keep doing exactly what it has done for the last 12 months.

I would only consider getting back in when there is actual trade happening with this company, not airy, fairy promises that seem to take them down blind alleys (EVOO/ONION/SEA-VOO) ... to date there has been no substance to the new CEO & Directors coming onto the BOD. The only thing that is attractive is the value of being listed on the main LSE market, giving the opportunity to be a RTO target to get a full listing on the cheap and quickly. That is what attracted me 3 years ago and I was able to trade out with a handsome profit on last year's rumour based rally. Too dangerous to get back in at the moment.

data.author: crober33
data.content: First off – no one sensible is “marrying” this share. That phrase gets thrown around whenever price pulls back, but risk management cuts both ways. Ignoring a setup because of past failures can be just as costly as blind faith. On charts (for Musk / chartists): Yes, the trend was down. Everyone can see that. But charts don’t predict news – they react to it. What changed recently isn’t price action, it’s structure: • New CFO and Audit Chair with cross-border M&A / IPO backgrounds • Formal strategic pivot into AI, SaaS, compute + energy infrastructure • Explicit wording around synergistic M&A and platform building • Asia-Pac focus with HK + Shenzhen hubs That’s not noise. That’s a corporate reset. Charts lag fundamentals at inflection points – and SCGL has form for violent re-ratings once sentiment flips (people seem to forget 0.07 → 1.3p didn’t come from “good charts”). On EVOO / “no mention = dead”: Silence ≠ cancellation. If anything, this RNS broadens the scope beyond one JV. Companies don’t narrow vision when something collapses – they do it when they’re building optionality. EVOO can still sit inside a wider AI / compute platform rather than being the headline On “AI bubble bursting”: The bubble isn’t AI – it’s unrevenue AI. Compute, infrastructure, energy assurance and SaaS tooling are exactly where real money is flowing. That’s what this RNS points toward.

data.author: Colenal
data.content: Kentan - It's not indulgence, I can't speak for OSD or anyone else, I genuinely agree with most of your thoughts. With regard to jumping ship, that is a choice for individuals to make for themselves, I believe one person with a sizeable interest has done that, I don't know his figures on that, none of my business. For myself I did say the other day that I could have escaped alive a couple of weeks ago, my break even is .77, but I chose to see if it would rise of it's own accord or if the band of day-trippers would help it higher, I don't mind how it happens, a profit is a profit. I sometimes see posts criticising people for commenting when they aren't invested here, personally it doesn't bother me if I believe that their words are spoken with honesty and I feel I might learn something, it is the day trippers who turn up trying to convince me that they love this and my opinions are unfairly negative that irk  me. If I am still here in a year it isn't that I'm ignoring what might be good advice, it's that my stake here is very small and I view it as sh*t or bust.

data.author: kentan
data.content: Colenal & OSD, thank you for your indulgence of me, I am only trying to be straightforward and honest ... whereas SCGL are not totally so. My first assumption on this latest RNS was they were hoping the SP would rise on it to give them the opportnity to fund raise at around 1p, but that seems dead in the water now that realizations have come to bear the price down. To make it viable and attractive now, they need to issue more shares at a discount (realisticly, say at 0.25p = to 1/4 of a penny) for 80m shares = £200k to cover interim funding and share offers to the 2 new directors  ... that means further dilution of the current share price to around 0.3p. The questions you now have to ask yourselves, .... "Is it worth me being in this share"? .... "Do I get out now to cut my losses"? .... "Will I ever see my money again"? .... "Do I trust the BOD of SCGL"? .... I hope I am wrong, but it doesn't look good to me.
