data.author: Bigw77
data.content: Given the BODs need for issuing previous speeding tickets, I can't help feeling like they want to issue information piecemeal. Just reviewing the specific wording and with a bit of use of AI myself, this is wat it tells me. "Dual-Hub" Strategy for Greater Bay Area: Chinese-language coverage and regional business outlets are highlighting the formalization of a Shenzhen hub for Mainland China operations and a Hong Kong hub for Southeast Asian expansion. This positioning is intended to leverage Shenzhen's tech manufacturing power for the new "computing infrastructure" push. Infrastructure & Energy Assurance: Rather than just a luxury app, the press notes that the project is now building out computing-power infrastructure and energy technology. This aligns with broader Chinese national strategies to integrate AI into energy systems to support high-intensity processing. Expansion into B2B SaaS: The latest reports indicate that SEA-VOO is moving beyond direct-to-consumer luxury retail to offer AI-driven SaaS digital management tools for businesses. My own concern from this is that if there is a desire to build datacentres they will oodles of cash, that won't com from a raise though, more likely a JV I'd say

data.author: callit
data.content: After a little bit of digging this bit of the RNS stands out to me: "Computing-power infrastructure and energy technology, with the aim of building a more integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance." It seems that after the US bans on exporting NVIDIA GPU's and then backtracking, China has now started restricting them themselves. https://scanx.trade/stock-market-news/global/nvidia-ceo-jensen-huang-visits-china-as-h200-chips-face-customs-restrictions/30787877 It got me thinking, what if someone were to build datacenters of NVIDIA GPU's just outside the China border and then supply computing into China? Then I thought could this be done from Hong Kong, Is Hong King subject to the same restrictions? So I asked GPT. Take this wit a pinch of salt as it's often wrong but, this was the result: "NVIDIA GPU Restrictions and Hong Kong Current Status of Restrictions The restrictions placed on the import of NVIDIA GPUs and advanced semiconductors primarily target mainland China. Hong Kong, operating under a separate customs regime, generally enjoys more lenient access to technology and components. This means: Import Controls: The stringent export controls and restrictions imposed by the U.S. on semiconductor technology largely do not apply to Hong Kong in the same way they do to mainland China. Procurement Flexibility: Companies in Hong Kong often have greater flexibility to import high-tech components, including NVIDIA GPUs, compared to those in mainland China. Regulatory Framework: Hong Kong has its own regulatory system, which differs from that of mainland China, making it easier for companies to access new technologies. Limitations and Considerations While Hong Kong has significant advantages regarding access to NVIDIA GPUs, businesses must be mindful of: Evolving Geopolitical Landscape: As international dynamics shift, potential policy changes could impact access in the future. Compliance Requirements: Companies must ensure compliance with both local laws and relevant international regulations, even in Hong Kong. Conclusion Currently, Hong Kong is not subject to the same restrictions on the import of NVIDIA GPUs as applies to mainland China, making it a strategic location for establishing data centers to meet the demand for advanced computing resources. Would you like more information on logistic considerations or any other specific aspect?" It struck me in he article that the large Chinese AI companies would like to get access to NVIDIA GPU`s include our old friend Tencent(See previous RNS's about JV with Tencent subsidiary). Of course we also have links to NVIDIA through their connect programme. Seems we could be in the sweet spot. Anyway all putting 2 + 2 together and getting 5 and who knows if GPT speaks with forked tongue. Certainly interesting times ahead. GLA DYOR

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: The latest announcements from Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) directly align with the SEA-VOO AI ASIA initiative by transitioning it from a conceptual partnership into an active, operational phase. In short, the recent updates move SEA-VOO from a "strategic vision" to a technically-backed, well-funded project with a clear path to market through established engineering partners. Key points of alignment include: Platform Development: Sealand selected Vacuumlabs as the strategic development partner for the SEA-VOO rollout. Vacuumlabs will build the technical infrastructure to integrate EVOO's AI with Sealand’s payment and distribution systems. Expansion of AI Scope: While SEA-VOO was originally focused on a "best-in-class luxury commerce experience", the latest updates expand this to include AI-driven SaaS digital management tools. This allows Sealand to offer business-to-business (B2B) services alongside its consumer-facing e-commerce platform. Infrastructure & Technical Validation: The alignment is further strengthened by EVOO AI’s acceptance into the NVIDIA Connect Program. This provides SEA-VOO with advanced AI tools and reduced computing costs, accelerating the roadmap for AI-powered personalization in the luxury market. Operational "Dual-Hub" Strategy: Sealand’s move to establish hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong provides the physical and legal framework needed for SEA-VOO to target the broader APAC market while maintaining exclusive rights to EVOO’s Olive technology in the region. Leadership for Scaling: Recent appointments, including a new CFO and Independent Non-Executive Director with cross-border transaction expertise, are designed to oversee the financial and strategic scaling of the SEA-VOO venture.

data.author: crober33
data.content: This RNS shouldn’t be dismissed as “just words” — it actually ties together everything we’ve seen recently. For the first time, SCGL has formally locked in: • AI + SaaS as the core focus • computing power + energy infrastructure • Asia-Pacific as the execution base • and explicit consideration of synergistic M&A That explains the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments perfectly. You don’t bring in IPO, cross-border M&A and capital-markets specialists unless you’re planning something more ambitious than business-as-usual. The mention of: “integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance” …is a huge step up from a single-project narrative. This positions SCGL as a platform vehicle, not a punt on one app. At a ~£4m market cap, the market is still valuing SCGL as if none of this matters. But companies don’t publish a prospectus, restructure their board, pivot strategy and openly flag M&A unless they believe execution is coming. This feels like the groundwork phase before something more concrete — whether that’s asset injection, partnership, funding or corporate action. Still speculative? Yes. But dismissing this as meaningless now looks increasingly wrong. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: Wulfgar
data.content: If you run a scenario like this using Ai, it does look possible: For Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (SCGL) to reach a share price of £1 (100 GBX) from its current level of approximately 0.445p, it would require a valuation increase of over 22,000%. As of February 2026, the stock is highly speculative, with a market capitalisation of roughly £4.39 million. Potential catalysts that could drive such a significant price movement include: Artificial Intelligence (AI) Expansion: The company is undergoing a major strategic shift toward AI and high-growth technology. Successful deployment of its intended AI-led software tools and computing-power infrastructure, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region (hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong), could serve as a massive growth driver. Successful Acquisitions: Sealand operates as a proactive acquirer. Completing its ongoing due diligence and finalized investment in EVOO AI plc (or similar high-value tech entities) could significantly alter its fundamental value. Monetisation of "Olive": Scaling its luxury e-commerce marketplace, Olive, which uses AI learning tools for personalized shopping experiences in the luxury goods sector, could lead to the revenue growth necessary to justify a higher valuation. Turnaround in Financials: Currently, the company face severe financial weakness, including a net profit margin of -368.11% and ongoing losses (£361,985 for H1 2025). A catalyst would be achieving consistent profitability and positive cash flow, which it currently lacks. Market Speculation: Historically, SCGL has experienced massive volatility, such as a 4,500% surge within a 180-day period in late 2024/early 2025. While speculative, such momentum-driven moves often occur in low-cap stocks in high-interest sectors like AI. Key Insights High Beta: With a beta of 1.06 to 1.12, the stock is highly sensitive to broader market movements, potentially amplifying gains during bullish sentiment in the tech sector. Insider Alignment: Individual insiders own approximately 56% of the company, suggesting management's interests are closely aligned with seeing the share price rise. Risks: Reaching £1 would require an extraordinary shift in fundamentals, as the current 52-week high is 5.5p. Severe financial weaknesses and negative equity remain major hurdles. We can dream though!

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Colenal - something you may be interested in - We have walked up the hill this morning to Kefalos Village. I am going to help grind some wheat & other stuff for Nic & his family to produce flour for their restaurant and neighbouring bakeries. They only grind once or twice a month and it has become quite a local treat - filling their coffers with all the coffee and cake they sell !! It is the last working windmill on Kos and is so interesting - especially being involved - usually lugging bags down the cave walks to the storage area. You can find the details if you go on Google earth and put in either Mylotopi restaurant or windmill. The view from up here is fabulous. And just a thought why I have posted this - it is an example of a business literally turning fresh air into a valuable asset :) May SCGL learn how to do that - it would be wonderful !! OSD - hoping to get a free slice of cake :)

data.author: callit
data.content: Colenal, you are entitled to take a cautious approach if you see fit, but that analogy doesn`t match what we have here. More like they borrowed £10 and said they would pay it back in a year, 10 months later they say hello to you but don't mention the money. They don't ask for any further money, and now you wonder will I get the £10 in a few months as promised. They haven't defaulted on the debt. If you borrowed that money from a bank you wouldn't expect them to send the debt collectors until the debt was actually not paid within agreed time limits. You wouldn't expect them to have repossessed your car before the debt was up and then said it was because you didn't contact them to say you were still going to pay what was owed. It's the act of defaulting on the act of defaulting on the debt that is important, it matters not if there is communication on some other topic and no mention of the debt. If it's not in default it's not in default. The 'Summer' date is something people got from EVOO's website. It's nothing to do with Sealand or SEAVOO, though there may be a requirement for SEAVOO to use technology developed by EVOO and a delay of EVOO may make some doubt a bit more how that technology is progressing. SUMMER launch was never RNS'd for SEAVOO. Expected news in the 4th quarter, which will be in alignment with the financial year not the calendar year I would assume. GLA DYOR

data.author: Colenal
data.content: To what extent ? A slightly higher extent than we should consider it to have gone well. If you lent someone £10 a year ago on the promise it would be repaid the next day and they disappeared until last week asking for another  £10 loan promising to repay it the next day you wouldn't believe them. I am happy  to believe that we might get get lucky here if and when the day-trippers return and pump it a bit higher than their last effort, but to get excited about that R.N.S. that talked much and said little is not for me, and I know I am not alone in thinking that way. I am fully aware that we are gambling and like everyone else I don't care what takes the S.P. up but this horse is the rank outsider in the race and all the ifs, mights or coulds will not change that no matter how much we try to talk it up. Again recently the talk has turned to sellers being finished, and MMs playing games to let their friends in. If we go back 6 months the S.P. was at a similar level and the posts were exactly the same 'MMs playing games',  'they will have to let this go soon',  'letting their friends in cheap' ,  none of those posters have been right yet but if this goes near .5 they will all scream 'this it, 1p before close.' We may get rich here but don't hold your breath. All I am saying is live in the real world.

data.author: callit
data.content: Response from AI: "Proportion of Software Projects Launched Late Approximately 90% of software projects face delays beyond their initially stated release dates. This statistic highlights the significant challenges within software development, with many factors contributing to these delays. Key Factors Contributing to Delays Late Stage Design Changes: A predominant reason cited for delays is modifications made during late stages of development, which can often be within the control of the engineering teams. Poor Estimation and Planning: Many projects suffer from inaccurate estimations regarding the time and resources needed for completion, leading to overruns. Resource Allocation Issues: Shortages in key components or issues with international shipping can also impact timelines. Breakdown of Project Success Rates Only 31% of software projects are completed on time and within budget. Around 52% are considered "challenged," meaning they either run over budget or miss deadlines but are still launched. 19% are outright failures, meaning they are abandoned entirely before launch. Conclusion The high percentage of delayed software releases points to a systemic issue in project management and estimation. Understanding these factors can help organizations improve their planning and potentially reduce the incidence of delays in future projects." So the real questions is, if 90% of software projects are launched late, to what extent should we consider delays in the launch of SEAVOO to mean it all went belly up? GLA DYOR

data.author: crober33
data.content: Worth remembering the Vacuumlabs RNS (strategic development partner) only landed late Feb 2025. That’s effectively when the build clock started. For an AI-enabled platform of this scope, a realistic timeline is: 6–9 months for an MVP / pilot 9–15 months for something commercially usable That puts the earliest meaningful outcomes Q4 2025, with more realistic progress updates Q1–Q2 2026 — especially given the broader AI/SaaS strategy now outlined. So delays ≠ nothing happening. Partner selected usually means work begins, not launch next month. Next sensible updates to look for would be: pilot / controlled rollout commercial partnerships revenue-linked milestones DYOR. GLA.

data.content: The beauty of charting is that it shows you market structure ,for investors like many here ,at first that need to know what is price doing ,not what you want it to do ,eliminating your own biases and understanding objectively ,so u look at the chart over a higher timeframe ,up ,down or sideways ,only 3 direction price can move .secondly ,using historical point of consideration poc,evaluate ,where the poss are that the likelyhood of price reaction snr ,support and resistance ,volume comes to play at thos areas you have the first indication ,with other indicators one can evaluate at where you want to enter and where you want to exit ,chart is not a crystal ball,its a way of evaluating probabilities ,and where the bias will be on your side ,with strict stop loss in place .it should be mechanical in disciplined ,...so here which way is price travelling 2.what is strength of the price rsi  3 MA 50 and 200,many use others ,but over time i use only 3 volume and rsi ,MA ,keeping the chart as clean as possible for simplicity ..if price is goin down i dont want to take part .knowing when to particpate can only come from charts ,not to enter or exit blindly https://invst.ly/1f134p

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Spot on, Colenal. Everything you’ve said hits the mark. No one here is “marrying” this share — it’s a small outsider punt, for most - nothing more, and treating it that way is the only sane approach given the lack of substance over the past year. Although I have all but written off ( mentally ) the investment, and will be delighted if my investment was returned. Fortunately it doesn't impact my overall investments in others - so that at least is a bonus. You’re absolutely right about the difference between negativity and realism. If the old circus rolled back in and pumped this to silly levels again, half the board would be cheering them on while sprinting for the exit. The fact most holders would happily sell on even a modest rise tells you exactly how fragile the confidence really is. Your take on charts is bang on too. They show history, not destiny. Great for quick trades if you’re nimble, but for small players it’s just another gamble — like backing a horse after six wins and expecting value. And until an RNS is backed by something meaningful — not pocket‑change revenue or vague promises — this is likely to keep drifting exactly as it has. That’s not being negative, that’s just calling the race as it’s running. Solid post, well put. data.author: Colenal
data.content: Lots of interesting points to take from those comments. With regard to marrying a share, that is a term I have read many times, some might, but I  am definitely not doing that here, I treat it as an outsider in the Grand National and if it sinks it is a small loss, but I wouldn't personally put a pound on it now. In my opinion there is a big difference between talking a share down in a negative manner and a healthy dose of realism, I don't feel we can bite both ends of the biscuit, not many would complain if the band of clowns returned and talked this up to a level that gave them multiples of their investment back. Most have forgotten what has taken this up in the past year, the answer is very little, and most would rush for the door on a rise a little higher than earlier this month, which says to me that they have little more faith than Kentan or myself, the only difference being that he isn't in this and we are. When it comes to charts, I said before, I have little understanding, but the one thing I have noticed is exactly what has just been said, they give information on what has happened, not what will happen, I can see that you can use them for a quick 10% but they wouldn't work for a small player like me, you don't get the best price on a horse that has just had 6 straight wins, stuff like this is just a gamble. As always the amateur is sorry to anyone I have offended but until something that is announced in an R.N.S. is actually backed up by something meaningful rather than accounts saying that the revenue paid the milkman then I think this is going to keep doing exactly what it has done for the last 12 months.

data.author: crober33
data.content: First off – no one sensible is “marrying” this share. That phrase gets thrown around whenever price pulls back, but risk management cuts both ways. Ignoring a setup because of past failures can be just as costly as blind faith. On charts (for Musk / chartists): Yes, the trend was down. Everyone can see that. But charts don’t predict news – they react to it. What changed recently isn’t price action, it’s structure: • New CFO and Audit Chair with cross-border M&A / IPO backgrounds • Formal strategic pivot into AI, SaaS, compute + energy infrastructure • Explicit wording around synergistic M&A and platform building • Asia-Pac focus with HK + Shenzhen hubs That’s not noise. That’s a corporate reset. Charts lag fundamentals at inflection points – and SCGL has form for violent re-ratings once sentiment flips (people seem to forget 0.07 → 1.3p didn’t come from “good charts”). On EVOO / “no mention = dead”: Silence ≠ cancellation. If anything, this RNS broadens the scope beyond one JV. Companies don’t narrow vision when something collapses – they do it when they’re building optionality. EVOO can still sit inside a wider AI / compute platform rather than being the headline On “AI bubble bursting”: The bubble isn’t AI – it’s unrevenue AI. Compute, infrastructure, energy assurance and SaaS tooling are exactly where real money is flowing. That’s what this RNS points toward.

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: Given the BODs need for issuing previous speeding tickets, I can't help feeling like they want to issue information piecemeal. Just reviewing the specific wording and with a bit of use of AI myself, this is wat it tells me. "Dual-Hub" Strategy for Greater Bay Area: Chinese-language coverage and regional business outlets are highlighting the formalization of a Shenzhen hub for Mainland China operations and a Hong Kong hub for Southeast Asian expansion. This positioning is intended to leverage Shenzhen's tech manufacturing power for the new "computing infrastructure" push. Infrastructure & Energy Assurance: Rather than just a luxury app, the press notes that the project is now building out computing-power infrastructure and energy technology. This aligns with broader Chinese national strategies to integrate AI into energy systems to support high-intensity processing. Expansion into B2B SaaS: The latest reports indicate that SEA-VOO is moving beyond direct-to-consumer luxury retail to offer AI-driven SaaS digital management tools for businesses. My own concern from this is that if there is a desire to build datacentres they will oodles of cash, that won't com from a raise though, more likely a JV I'd say

data.author: callit
data.content: After a little bit of digging this bit of the RNS stands out to me: "Computing-power infrastructure and energy technology, with the aim of building a more integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance." It seems that after the US bans on exporting NVIDIA GPU's and then backtracking, China has now started restricting them themselves. https://scanx.trade/stock-market-news/global/nvidia-ceo-jensen-huang-visits-china-as-h200-chips-face-customs-restrictions/30787877 It got me thinking, what if someone were to build datacenters of NVIDIA GPU's just outside the China border and then supply computing into China? Then I thought could this be done from Hong Kong, Is Hong King subject to the same restrictions? So I asked GPT. Take this wit a pinch of salt as it's often wrong but, this was the result: "NVIDIA GPU Restrictions and Hong Kong Current Status of Restrictions The restrictions placed on the import of NVIDIA GPUs and advanced semiconductors primarily target mainland China. Hong Kong, operating under a separate customs regime, generally enjoys more lenient access to technology and components. This means: Import Controls: The stringent export controls and restrictions imposed by the U.S. on semiconductor technology largely do not apply to Hong Kong in the same way they do to mainland China. Procurement Flexibility: Companies in Hong Kong often have greater flexibility to import high-tech components, including NVIDIA GPUs, compared to those in mainland China. Regulatory Framework: Hong Kong has its own regulatory system, which differs from that of mainland China, making it easier for companies to access new technologies. Limitations and Considerations While Hong Kong has significant advantages regarding access to NVIDIA GPUs, businesses must be mindful of: Evolving Geopolitical Landscape: As international dynamics shift, potential policy changes could impact access in the future. Compliance Requirements: Companies must ensure compliance with both local laws and relevant international regulations, even in Hong Kong. Conclusion Currently, Hong Kong is not subject to the same restrictions on the import of NVIDIA GPUs as applies to mainland China, making it a strategic location for establishing data centers to meet the demand for advanced computing resources. Would you like more information on logistic considerations or any other specific aspect?" It struck me in he article that the large Chinese AI companies would like to get access to NVIDIA GPU`s include our old friend Tencent(See previous RNS's about JV with Tencent subsidiary). Of course we also have links to NVIDIA through their connect programme. Seems we could be in the sweet spot. Anyway all putting 2 + 2 together and getting 5 and who knows if GPT speaks with forked tongue. Certainly interesting times ahead. GLA DYOR

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: The latest announcements from Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) directly align with the SEA-VOO AI ASIA initiative by transitioning it from a conceptual partnership into an active, operational phase. In short, the recent updates move SEA-VOO from a "strategic vision" to a technically-backed, well-funded project with a clear path to market through established engineering partners. Key points of alignment include: Platform Development: Sealand selected Vacuumlabs as the strategic development partner for the SEA-VOO rollout. Vacuumlabs will build the technical infrastructure to integrate EVOO's AI with Sealand’s payment and distribution systems. Expansion of AI Scope: While SEA-VOO was originally focused on a "best-in-class luxury commerce experience", the latest updates expand this to include AI-driven SaaS digital management tools. This allows Sealand to offer business-to-business (B2B) services alongside its consumer-facing e-commerce platform. Infrastructure & Technical Validation: The alignment is further strengthened by EVOO AI’s acceptance into the NVIDIA Connect Program. This provides SEA-VOO with advanced AI tools and reduced computing costs, accelerating the roadmap for AI-powered personalization in the luxury market. Operational "Dual-Hub" Strategy: Sealand’s move to establish hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong provides the physical and legal framework needed for SEA-VOO to target the broader APAC market while maintaining exclusive rights to EVOO’s Olive technology in the region. Leadership for Scaling: Recent appointments, including a new CFO and Independent Non-Executive Director with cross-border transaction expertise, are designed to oversee the financial and strategic scaling of the SEA-VOO venture.

data.author: crober33
data.content: This RNS shouldn’t be dismissed as “just words” — it actually ties together everything we’ve seen recently. For the first time, SCGL has formally locked in: • AI + SaaS as the core focus • computing power + energy infrastructure • Asia-Pacific as the execution base • and explicit consideration of synergistic M&A That explains the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments perfectly. You don’t bring in IPO, cross-border M&A and capital-markets specialists unless you’re planning something more ambitious than business-as-usual. The mention of: “integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance” …is a huge step up from a single-project narrative. This positions SCGL as a platform vehicle, not a punt on one app. At a ~£4m market cap, the market is still valuing SCGL as if none of this matters. But companies don’t publish a prospectus, restructure their board, pivot strategy and openly flag M&A unless they believe execution is coming. This feels like the groundwork phase before something more concrete — whether that’s asset injection, partnership, funding or corporate action. Still speculative? Yes. But dismissing this as meaningless now looks increasingly wrong. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: Wulfgar
data.content: If you run a scenario like this using Ai, it does look possible: For Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (SCGL) to reach a share price of £1 (100 GBX) from its current level of approximately 0.445p, it would require a valuation increase of over 22,000%. As of February 2026, the stock is highly speculative, with a market capitalisation of roughly £4.39 million. Potential catalysts that could drive such a significant price movement include: Artificial Intelligence (AI) Expansion: The company is undergoing a major strategic shift toward AI and high-growth technology. Successful deployment of its intended AI-led software tools and computing-power infrastructure, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region (hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong), could serve as a massive growth driver. Successful Acquisitions: Sealand operates as a proactive acquirer. Completing its ongoing due diligence and finalized investment in EVOO AI plc (or similar high-value tech entities) could significantly alter its fundamental value. Monetisation of "Olive": Scaling its luxury e-commerce marketplace, Olive, which uses AI learning tools for personalized shopping experiences in the luxury goods sector, could lead to the revenue growth necessary to justify a higher valuation. Turnaround in Financials: Currently, the company face severe financial weakness, including a net profit margin of -368.11% and ongoing losses (£361,985 for H1 2025). A catalyst would be achieving consistent profitability and positive cash flow, which it currently lacks. Market Speculation: Historically, SCGL has experienced massive volatility, such as a 4,500% surge within a 180-day period in late 2024/early 2025. While speculative, such momentum-driven moves often occur in low-cap stocks in high-interest sectors like AI. Key Insights High Beta: With a beta of 1.06 to 1.12, the stock is highly sensitive to broader market movements, potentially amplifying gains during bullish sentiment in the tech sector. Insider Alignment: Individual insiders own approximately 56% of the company, suggesting management's interests are closely aligned with seeing the share price rise. Risks: Reaching £1 would require an extraordinary shift in fundamentals, as the current 52-week high is 5.5p. Severe financial weaknesses and negative equity remain major hurdles. We can dream though!

data.author: callit
data.content: Colenal, you are entitled to take a cautious approach if you see fit, but that analogy doesn`t match what we have here. More like they borrowed £10 and said they would pay it back in a year, 10 months later they say hello to you but don't mention the money. They don't ask for any further money, and now you wonder will I get the £10 in a few months as promised. They haven't defaulted on the debt. If you borrowed that money from a bank you wouldn't expect them to send the debt collectors until the debt was actually not paid within agreed time limits. You wouldn't expect them to have repossessed your car before the debt was up and then said it was because you didn't contact them to say you were still going to pay what was owed. It's the act of defaulting on the act of defaulting on the debt that is important, it matters not if there is communication on some other topic and no mention of the debt. If it's not in default it's not in default. The 'Summer' date is something people got from EVOO's website. It's nothing to do with Sealand or SEAVOO, though there may be a requirement for SEAVOO to use technology developed by EVOO and a delay of EVOO may make some doubt a bit more how that technology is progressing. SUMMER launch was never RNS'd for SEAVOO. Expected news in the 4th quarter, which will be in alignment with the financial year not the calendar year I would assume. GLA DYOR

data.author: callit
data.content: Response from AI: "Proportion of Software Projects Launched Late Approximately 90% of software projects face delays beyond their initially stated release dates. This statistic highlights the significant challenges within software development, with many factors contributing to these delays. Key Factors Contributing to Delays Late Stage Design Changes: A predominant reason cited for delays is modifications made during late stages of development, which can often be within the control of the engineering teams. Poor Estimation and Planning: Many projects suffer from inaccurate estimations regarding the time and resources needed for completion, leading to overruns. Resource Allocation Issues: Shortages in key components or issues with international shipping can also impact timelines. Breakdown of Project Success Rates Only 31% of software projects are completed on time and within budget. Around 52% are considered "challenged," meaning they either run over budget or miss deadlines but are still launched. 19% are outright failures, meaning they are abandoned entirely before launch. Conclusion The high percentage of delayed software releases points to a systemic issue in project management and estimation. Understanding these factors can help organizations improve their planning and potentially reduce the incidence of delays in future projects." So the real questions is, if 90% of software projects are launched late, to what extent should we consider delays in the launch of SEAVOO to mean it all went belly up? GLA DYOR

data.author: crober33
data.content: Worth remembering the Vacuumlabs RNS (strategic development partner) only landed late Feb 2025. That’s effectively when the build clock started. For an AI-enabled platform of this scope, a realistic timeline is: 6–9 months for an MVP / pilot 9–15 months for something commercially usable That puts the earliest meaningful outcomes Q4 2025, with more realistic progress updates Q1–Q2 2026 — especially given the broader AI/SaaS strategy now outlined. So delays ≠ nothing happening. Partner selected usually means work begins, not launch next month. Next sensible updates to look for would be: pilot / controlled rollout commercial partnerships revenue-linked milestones DYOR. GLA.

data.author: msuk.int
data.content: The beauty of charting is that it shows you market structure ,for investors like many here ,at first that need to know what is price doing ,not what you want it to do ,eliminating your own biases and understanding objectively ,so u look at the chart over a higher timeframe ,up ,down or sideways ,only 3 direction price can move .secondly ,using historical point of consideration poc,evaluate ,where the poss are that the likelyhood of price reaction snr ,support and resistance ,volume comes to play at thos areas you have the first indication ,with other indicators one can evaluate at where you want to enter and where you want to exit ,chart is not a crystal ball,its a way of evaluating probabilities ,and where the bias will be on your side ,with strict stop loss in place .it should be mechanical in disciplined ,...so here which way is price travelling 2.what is strength of the price rsi  3 MA 50 and 200,many use others ,but over time i use only 3 volume and rsi ,MA ,keeping the chart as clean as possible for simplicity ..if price is goin down i dont want to take part .knowing when to particpate can only come from charts ,not to enter or exit blindly https://invst.ly/1f134p

No one here is “marrying” this share — it’s a small outsider punt, for most - nothing more, and treating it that way is the only sane approach given the lack of substance over the past year. The fact most holders would happily sell on even a modest rise tells you exactly how fragile the confidence really is. Your take on charts is bang on too. They show history, not destiny. Great for quick trades if you’re nimble, but for small players it’s just another gamble — like backing a horse after six wins and expecting value. And until an RNS is backed by something meaningful — not pocket‑change revenue or vague promises — this is likely to keep drifting exactly as it has. data.author: Colenal
data.content: Lots of interesting points to take from those comments. With regard to marrying a share, that is a term I have read many times, some might, but I  am definitely not doing that here, I treat it as an outsider in the Grand National and if it sinks it is a small loss, but I wouldn't personally put a pound on it now. In my opinion there is a big difference between talking a share down in a negative manner and a healthy dose of realism, I don't feel we can bite both ends of the biscuit, not many would complain if the band of clowns returned and talked this up to a level that gave them multiples of their investment back. Most have forgotten what has taken this up in the past year, the answer is very little, and most would rush for the door on a rise a little higher than earlier this month, which says to me that they have little more faith than Kentan or myself, the only difference being that he isn't in this and we are. When it comes to charts, I said before, I have little understanding, but the one thing I have noticed is exactly what has just been said, they give information on what has happened, not what will happen, I can see that you can use them for a quick 10% but they wouldn't work for a small player like me, you don't get the best price on a horse that has just had 6 straight wins, stuff like this is just a gamble. As always the amateur is sorry to anyone I have offended but until something that is announced in an R.N.S. is actually backed up by something meaningful rather than accounts saying that the revenue paid the milkman then I think this is going to keep doing exactly what it has done for the last 12 months.

data.author: crober33
data.content: First off – no one sensible is “marrying” this share. That phrase gets thrown around whenever price pulls back, but risk management cuts both ways. Ignoring a setup because of past failures can be just as costly as blind faith. On charts (for Musk / chartists): Yes, the trend was down. Everyone can see that. But charts don’t predict news – they react to it. What changed recently isn’t price action, it’s structure: • New CFO and Audit Chair with cross-border M&A / IPO backgrounds • Formal strategic pivot into AI, SaaS, compute + energy infrastructure • Explicit wording around synergistic M&A and platform building • Asia-Pac focus with HK + Shenzhen hubs That’s not noise. That’s a corporate reset. Charts lag fundamentals at inflection points – and SCGL has form for violent re-ratings once sentiment flips (people seem to forget 0.07 → 1.3p didn’t come from “good charts”). On EVOO / “no mention = dead”: Silence ≠ cancellation. If anything, this RNS broadens the scope beyond one JV. Companies don’t narrow vision when something collapses – they do it when they’re building optionality. EVOO can still sit inside a wider AI / compute platform rather than being the headline On “AI bubble bursting”: The bubble isn’t AI – it’s unrevenue AI. Compute, infrastructure, energy assurance and SaaS tooling are exactly where real money is flowing. That’s what this RNS points toward.

Expansion into B2B SaaS: The latest reports indicate that SEA-VOO is moving beyond direct-to-consumer luxury retail to offer AI-driven SaaS digital management tools for businesses. data.author: callit
data.content: After a little bit of digging this bit of the RNS stands out to me: "Computing-power infrastructure and energy technology, with the aim of building a more integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance." It seems that after the US bans on exporting NVIDIA GPU's and then backtracking, China has now started restricting them themselves. https://scanx.trade/stock-market-news/global/nvidia-ceo-jensen-huang-visits-china-as-h200-chips-face-customs-restrictions/30787877 It got me thinking, what if someone were to build datacenters of NVIDIA GPU's just outside the China border and then supply computing into China? Then I thought could this be done from Hong Kong, Is Hong King subject to the same restrictions? So I asked GPT. Take this wit a pinch of salt as it's often wrong but, this was the result: "NVIDIA GPU Restrictions and Hong Kong Current Status of Restrictions The restrictions placed on the import of NVIDIA GPUs and advanced semiconductors primarily target mainland China. Hong Kong, operating under a separate customs regime, generally enjoys more lenient access to technology and components. This means: Import Controls: The stringent export controls and restrictions imposed by the U.S. on semiconductor technology largely do not apply to Hong Kong in the same way they do to mainland China. Procurement Flexibility: Companies in Hong Kong often have greater flexibility to import high-tech components, including NVIDIA GPUs, compared to those in mainland China. Regulatory Framework: Hong Kong has its own regulatory system, which differs from that of mainland China, making it easier for companies to access new technologies. Limitations and Considerations While Hong Kong has significant advantages regarding access to NVIDIA GPUs, businesses must be mindful of: Evolving Geopolitical Landscape: As international dynamics shift, potential policy changes could impact access in the future. Compliance Requirements: Companies must ensure compliance with both local laws and relevant international regulations, even in Hong Kong. Conclusion Currently, Hong Kong is not subject to the same restrictions on the import of NVIDIA GPUs as applies to mainland China, making it a strategic location for establishing data centers to meet the demand for advanced computing resources. Would you like more information on logistic considerations or any other specific aspect?" It struck me in he article that the large Chinese AI companies would like to get access to NVIDIA GPU`s include our old friend Tencent(See previous RNS's about JV with Tencent subsidiary). Of course we also have links to NVIDIA through their connect programme. Seems we could be in the sweet spot. Anyway all putting 2 + 2 together and getting 5 and who knows if GPT speaks with forked tongue. Certainly interesting times ahead. GLA DYOR

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: The latest announcements from Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) directly align with the SEA-VOO AI ASIA initiative by transitioning it from a conceptual partnership into an active, operational phase. In short, the recent updates move SEA-VOO from a "strategic vision" to a technically-backed, well-funded project with a clear path to market through established engineering partners. Key points of alignment include: Platform Development: Sealand selected Vacuumlabs as the strategic development partner for the SEA-VOO rollout. Vacuumlabs will build the technical infrastructure to integrate EVOO's AI with Sealand’s payment and distribution systems. Expansion of AI Scope: While SEA-VOO was originally focused on a "best-in-class luxury commerce experience", the latest updates expand this to include AI-driven SaaS digital management tools. This allows Sealand to offer business-to-business (B2B) services alongside its consumer-facing e-commerce platform. Infrastructure & Technical Validation: The alignment is further strengthened by EVOO AI’s acceptance into the NVIDIA Connect Program. This provides SEA-VOO with advanced AI tools and reduced computing costs, accelerating the roadmap for AI-powered personalization in the luxury market. Operational "Dual-Hub" Strategy: Sealand’s move to establish hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong provides the physical and legal framework needed for SEA-VOO to target the broader APAC market while maintaining exclusive rights to EVOO’s Olive technology in the region. Leadership for Scaling: Recent appointments, including a new CFO and Independent Non-Executive Director with cross-border transaction expertise, are designed to oversee the financial and strategic scaling of the SEA-VOO venture.

data.author: crober33
data.content: This RNS shouldn’t be dismissed as “just words” — it actually ties together everything we’ve seen recently. For the first time, SCGL has formally locked in: • AI + SaaS as the core focus • computing power + energy infrastructure • Asia-Pacific as the execution base • and explicit consideration of synergistic M&A That explains the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments perfectly. You don’t bring in IPO, cross-border M&A and capital-markets specialists unless you’re planning something more ambitious than business-as-usual. The mention of: “integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance” …is a huge step up from a single-project narrative. This positions SCGL as a platform vehicle, not a punt on one app. At a ~£4m market cap, the market is still valuing SCGL as if none of this matters. But companies don’t publish a prospectus, restructure their board, pivot strategy and openly flag M&A unless they believe execution is coming. This feels like the groundwork phase before something more concrete — whether that’s asset injection, partnership, funding or corporate action. Still speculative? Yes. But dismissing this as meaningless now looks increasingly wrong. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: kentan
data.content: Sailor, my posts are not words of regret, far from it ... just a warning ... "A fool and his money are easily parted", especially when investing in a share like SCGL with encouragement from "no marks" who haven't a clue. For your information, I consider "risk to reward" before I invest in anything and from what has transpired I haven't missed any boats. Sealand provided me with a handsome profit that has been invested elsewhere and it has multiplied several times over, but it is not the best performer I have ever been involved in .... those that have been good to me have given me a wonderful life on the French Riviera, not far from Monaco, where I live for part of the year. I made my comments about the Sealand Capital Galaxy Ltd website that is woefully behind what has happened and is happening ... even the directors section on here is completely out of date and misleading. .... It seems that they badly need a "Communications Director" to update all aspects of this share, before I, or anyone else of a right mind, would consider investing in again.

data.author: kentan
data.content: Thought I would pay a visit to their official website to see what is going on .... and what a disappointment it was: https://www.sealandcapitalgalaxy.com/news Their latest news update was 20th January 2025 when Dr Thomas Sawyer was appointed as CEO ... that is now over a year ago and their media section posts are no better. So how can anyone take this company seriously when they treat their investors like this? I am not trying to deramp this share, I just want to show how dangerous it is to invest in a company like SCGL who show no regard for their faithful investors. My view is that any encouraging news will soon be followed by a cash call and further dilution of the SP (no matter what they have in reserve), the 2 new appointments to the board will surely be given decent share distributions that will impact the share structure of SCGL  ... I am sorry if this upsets some on here, but it must be taken into account if you consider throwing your money at this share, on what amounts to be speculative announcements from those who are seriously underwater to get the SP to rise again. I genuinely want all investors to profit from their support of SCGL ... but please, please be careful.

data.content: OSD - I do genuinely hope so, I try never to get to angry these days, at my age it isn't good for my health, and although we all get grouchy some days it probably serves little purpose. data.author: Bobat123
data.content: Based on recent market information (as of early February 2026), there appears to be significant confusion or speculation regarding a £1.70 analyst price target for Sealand Capital Galaxy Ltd (SCGL). Current Price Context: As of early February 2026, SCGL shares are trading in the range of 0.30p to 0.45p (roughly £0.003 - £0.0045). The £1.70 Target: Discussions on investor forums (e.g., London South East) mention an "analyst price target range from £1.65 to £1.775". data.author: Wulfgar
data.content: If you run a scenario like this using Ai, it does look possible: For Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (SCGL) to reach a share price of £1 (100 GBX) from its current level of approximately 0.445p, it would require a valuation increase of over 22,000%. As of February 2026, the stock is highly speculative, with a market capitalisation of roughly £4.39 million. Potential catalysts that could drive such a significant price movement include: Artificial Intelligence (AI) Expansion: The company is undergoing a major strategic shift toward AI and high-growth technology. Successful deployment of its intended AI-led software tools and computing-power infrastructure, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region (hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong), could serve as a massive growth driver. Successful Acquisitions: Sealand operates as a proactive acquirer. Completing its ongoing due diligence and finalized investment in EVOO AI plc (or similar high-value tech entities) could significantly alter its fundamental value. Monetisation of "Olive": Scaling its luxury e-commerce marketplace, Olive, which uses AI learning tools for personalized shopping experiences in the luxury goods sector, could lead to the revenue growth necessary to justify a higher valuation. Turnaround in Financials: Currently, the company face severe financial weakness, including a net profit margin of -368.11% and ongoing losses (£361,985 for H1 2025). A catalyst would be achieving consistent profitability and positive cash flow, which it currently lacks. Market Speculation: Historically, SCGL has experienced massive volatility, such as a 4,500% surge within a 180-day period in late 2024/early 2025. While speculative, such momentum-driven moves often occur in low-cap stocks in high-interest sectors like AI. Key Insights High Beta: With a beta of 1.06 to 1.12, the stock is highly sensitive to broader market movements, potentially amplifying gains during bullish sentiment in the tech sector. Insider Alignment: Individual insiders own approximately 56% of the company, suggesting management's interests are closely aligned with seeing the share price rise. Risks: Reaching £1 would require an extraordinary shift in fundamentals, as the current 52-week high is 5.5p. Severe financial weaknesses and negative equity remain major hurdles. We can dream though!

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Colenal - something you may be interested in - We have walked up the hill this morning to Kefalos Village. I am going to help grind some wheat & other stuff for Nic & his family to produce flour for their restaurant and neighbouring bakeries. They only grind once or twice a month and it has become quite a local treat - filling their coffers with all the coffee and cake they sell !! It is the last working windmill on Kos and is so interesting - especially being involved - usually lugging bags down the cave walks to the storage area. You can find the details if you go on Google earth and put in either Mylotopi restaurant or windmill. The view from up here is fabulous. And just a thought why I have posted this - it is an example of a business literally turning fresh air into a valuable asset :) May SCGL learn how to do that - it would be wonderful !! OSD - hoping to get a free slice of cake :)

data.author: Colenal
data.content: OSD - The first line of your post is exactly how i feel. I most definitely do not come on here to teach granny how to suck eggs. I was probably one of the first to get restless here, which I know doesn't sit well with some, but I want this to work, nobody talked this into remaining at such such a low level, least of all me, and certainly not the B.O.D. who say nothing at all. I hate it when the usual suspects turn up to gloat, but they wouldn't be here to gloat if there was anything meaningful happening here, they are looking to make money too, even when the day-trippers came they couldn't  get this up to 1p, which shows, up, down or sideways, we can't wish this to a place that suits us, the B.O.D. have to make that happen. data.author: callit
data.content: Colenal, you are entitled to take a cautious approach if you see fit, but that analogy doesn`t match what we have here. More like they borrowed £10 and said they would pay it back in a year, 10 months later they say hello to you but don't mention the money. They don't ask for any further money, and now you wonder will I get the £10 in a few months as promised. They haven't defaulted on the debt. If you borrowed that money from a bank you wouldn't expect them to send the debt collectors until the debt was actually not paid within agreed time limits. You wouldn't expect them to have repossessed your car before the debt was up and then said it was because you didn't contact them to say you were still going to pay what was owed. It's the act of defaulting on the act of defaulting on the debt that is important, it matters not if there is communication on some other topic and no mention of the debt. If it's not in default it's not in default. The 'Summer' date is something people got from EVOO's website. It's nothing to do with Sealand or SEAVOO, though there may be a requirement for SEAVOO to use technology developed by EVOO and a delay of EVOO may make some doubt a bit more how that technology is progressing. SUMMER launch was never RNS'd for SEAVOO. Expected news in the 4th quarter, which will be in alignment with the financial year not the calendar year I would assume. GLA DYOR

data.author: Colenal
data.content: To what extent ? A slightly higher extent than we should consider it to have gone well. If you lent someone £10 a year ago on the promise it would be repaid the next day and they disappeared until last week asking for another  £10 loan promising to repay it the next day you wouldn't believe them. I am happy  to believe that we might get get lucky here if and when the day-trippers return and pump it a bit higher than their last effort, but to get excited about that R.N.S. that talked much and said little is not for me, and I know I am not alone in thinking that way. I am fully aware that we are gambling and like everyone else I don't care what takes the S.P. up but this horse is the rank outsider in the race and all the ifs, mights or coulds will not change that no matter how much we try to talk it up. Again recently the talk has turned to sellers being finished, and MMs playing games to let their friends in. If we go back 6 months the S.P. was at a similar level and the posts were exactly the same 'MMs playing games',  'they will have to let this go soon',  'letting their friends in cheap' ,  none of those posters have been right yet but if this goes near .5 they will all scream 'this it, 1p before close.' We may get rich here but don't hold your breath. All I am saying is live in the real world.

data.author: callit
data.content: Response from AI: "Proportion of Software Projects Launched Late Approximately 90% of software projects face delays beyond their initially stated release dates. This statistic highlights the significant challenges within software development, with many factors contributing to these delays. Key Factors Contributing to Delays Late Stage Design Changes: A predominant reason cited for delays is modifications made during late stages of development, which can often be within the control of the engineering teams. Poor Estimation and Planning: Many projects suffer from inaccurate estimations regarding the time and resources needed for completion, leading to overruns. Resource Allocation Issues: Shortages in key components or issues with international shipping can also impact timelines. Breakdown of Project Success Rates Only 31% of software projects are completed on time and within budget. Around 52% are considered "challenged," meaning they either run over budget or miss deadlines but are still launched. 19% are outright failures, meaning they are abandoned entirely before launch. Conclusion The high percentage of delayed software releases points to a systemic issue in project management and estimation. Understanding these factors can help organizations improve their planning and potentially reduce the incidence of delays in future projects." So the real questions is, if 90% of software projects are launched late, to what extent should we consider delays in the launch of SEAVOO to mean it all went belly up? GLA DYOR

data.author: crober33
data.content: Worth remembering the Vacuumlabs RNS (strategic development partner) only landed late Feb 2025. That’s effectively when the build clock started. For an AI-enabled platform of this scope, a realistic timeline is: 6–9 months for an MVP / pilot 9–15 months for something commercially usable That puts the earliest meaningful outcomes Q4 2025, with more realistic progress updates Q1–Q2 2026 — especially given the broader AI/SaaS strategy now outlined. So delays ≠ nothing happening. Partner selected usually means work begins, not launch next month. Next sensible updates to look for would be: pilot / controlled rollout commercial partnerships revenue-linked milestones DYOR. GLA.

data.author: msuk.int
data.content: The beauty of charting is that it shows you market structure ,for investors like many here ,at first that need to know what is price doing ,not what you want it to do ,eliminating your own biases and understanding objectively ,so u look at the chart over a higher timeframe ,up ,down or sideways ,only 3 direction price can move .secondly ,using historical point of consideration poc,evaluate ,where the poss are that the likelyhood of price reaction snr ,support and resistance ,volume comes to play at thos areas you have the first indication ,with other indicators one can evaluate at where you want to enter and where you want to exit ,chart is not a crystal ball,its a way of evaluating probabilities ,and where the bias will be on your side ,with strict stop loss in place .it should be mechanical in disciplined ,...so here which way is price travelling 2.what is strength of the price rsi  3 MA 50 and 200,many use others ,but over time i use only 3 volume and rsi ,MA ,keeping the chart as clean as possible for simplicity ..if price is goin down i dont want to take part .knowing when to particpate can only come from charts ,not to enter or exit blindly https://invst.ly/1f134p

data.author: oldsharedog
data.content: Spot on, Colenal. Everything you’ve said hits the mark. No one here is “marrying” this share — it’s a small outsider punt, for most - nothing more, and treating it that way is the only sane approach given the lack of substance over the past year. I now have a more realistic holding here - far from where i was this time last year !!! Although I have all but written off ( mentally ) the investment, and will be delighted if my investment was returned. Fortunately it doesn't impact my overall investments in others - so that at least is a bonus. You’re absolutely right about the difference between negativity and realism. If the old circus rolled back in and pumped this to silly levels again, half the board would be cheering them on while sprinting for the exit. The fact most holders would happily sell on even a modest rise tells you exactly how fragile the confidence really is. Your take on charts is bang on too. They show history, not destiny. Great for quick trades if you’re nimble, but for small players it’s just another gamble — like backing a horse after six wins and expecting value. And until an RNS is backed by something meaningful — not pocket‑change revenue or vague promises — this is likely to keep drifting exactly as it has. That’s not being negative, that’s just calling the race as it’s running. Solid post, well put. OSD - Still trying to get the lister running smoothly - its like 10 little drummer boys at the moment - not the purring beauty i envisaged !!

data.author: Colenal
data.content: Lots of interesting points to take from those comments. With regard to marrying a share, that is a term I have read many times, some might, but I  am definitely not doing that here, I treat it as an outsider in the Grand National and if it sinks it is a small loss, but I wouldn't personally put a pound on it now. In my opinion there is a big difference between talking a share down in a negative manner and a healthy dose of realism, I don't feel we can bite both ends of the biscuit, not many would complain if the band of clowns returned and talked this up to a level that gave them multiples of their investment back. Most have forgotten what has taken this up in the past year, the answer is very little, and most would rush for the door on a rise a little higher than earlier this month, which says to me that they have little more faith than Kentan or myself, the only difference being that he isn't in this and we are. When it comes to charts, I said before, I have little understanding, but the one thing I have noticed is exactly what has just been said, they give information on what has happened, not what will happen, I can see that you can use them for a quick 10% but they wouldn't work for a small player like me, you don't get the best price on a horse that has just had 6 straight wins, stuff like this is just a gamble. As always the amateur is sorry to anyone I have offended but until something that is announced in an R.N.S. is actually backed up by something meaningful rather than accounts saying that the revenue paid the milkman then I think this is going to keep doing exactly what it has done for the last 12 months.

data.author: crober33
data.content: First off – no one sensible is “marrying” this share. That phrase gets thrown around whenever price pulls back, but risk management cuts both ways. Ignoring a setup because of past failures can be just as costly as blind faith. On charts (for Musk / chartists): Yes, the trend was down. Everyone can see that. But charts don’t predict news – they react to it. What changed recently isn’t price action, it’s structure: • New CFO and Audit Chair with cross-border M&A / IPO backgrounds • Formal strategic pivot into AI, SaaS, compute + energy infrastructure • Explicit wording around synergistic M&A and platform building • Asia-Pac focus with HK + Shenzhen hubs That’s not noise. That’s a corporate reset. Charts lag fundamentals at inflection points – and SCGL has form for violent re-ratings once sentiment flips (people seem to forget 0.07 → 1.3p didn’t come from “good charts”). On EVOO / “no mention = dead”: Silence ≠ cancellation. If anything, this RNS broadens the scope beyond one JV. Companies don’t narrow vision when something collapses – they do it when they’re building optionality. EVOO can still sit inside a wider AI / compute platform rather than being the headline On “AI bubble bursting”: The bubble isn’t AI – it’s unrevenue AI. Compute, infrastructure, energy assurance and SaaS tooling are exactly where real money is flowing. That’s what this RNS points toward.

data.author: Colenal
data.content: Kentan - It's not indulgence, I can't speak for OSD or anyone else, I genuinely agree with most of your thoughts. With regard to jumping ship, that is a choice for individuals to make for themselves, I believe one person with a sizeable interest has done that, I don't know his figures on that, none of my business. For myself I did say the other day that I could have escaped alive a couple of weeks ago, my break even is .77, but I chose to see if it would rise of it's own accord or if the band of day-trippers would help it higher, I don't mind how it happens, a profit is a profit. I sometimes see posts criticising people for commenting when they aren't invested here, personally it doesn't bother me if I believe that their words are spoken with honesty and I feel I might learn something, it is the day trippers who turn up trying to convince me that they love this and my opinions are unfairly negative that irk  me. If I am still here in a year it isn't that I'm ignoring what might be good advice, it's that my stake here is very small and I view it as sh*t or bust.

"Dual-Hub" Strategy for Greater Bay Area: Chinese-language coverage and regional business outlets are highlighting the formalization of a Shenzhen hub for Mainland China operations and a Hong Kong hub for Southeast Asian expansion. This positioning is intended to leverage Shenzhen's tech manufacturing power for the new "computing infrastructure" push. Infrastructure & Energy Assurance: Rather than just a luxury app, the press notes that the project is now building out computing-power infrastructure and energy technology. Expansion into B2B SaaS: The latest reports indicate that SEA-VOO is moving beyond direct-to-consumer luxury retail to offer AI-driven SaaS digital management tools for businesses. data.author: callit
data.content: After a little bit of digging this bit of the RNS stands out to me: "Computing-power infrastructure and energy technology, with the aim of building a more integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance." It seems that after the US bans on exporting NVIDIA GPU's and then backtracking, China has now started restricting them themselves. https://scanx.trade/stock-market-news/global/nvidia-ceo-jensen-huang-visits-china-as-h200-chips-face-customs-restrictions/30787877 It got me thinking, what if someone were to build datacenters of NVIDIA GPU's just outside the China border and then supply computing into China? Then I thought could this be done from Hong Kong, Is Hong King subject to the same restrictions? So I asked GPT. Take this wit a pinch of salt as it's often wrong but, this was the result: "NVIDIA GPU Restrictions and Hong Kong Current Status of Restrictions The restrictions placed on the import of NVIDIA GPUs and advanced semiconductors primarily target mainland China. Hong Kong, operating under a separate customs regime, generally enjoys more lenient access to technology and components. This means: Import Controls: The stringent export controls and restrictions imposed by the U.S. on semiconductor technology largely do not apply to Hong Kong in the same way they do to mainland China. Procurement Flexibility: Companies in Hong Kong often have greater flexibility to import high-tech components, including NVIDIA GPUs, compared to those in mainland China. Regulatory Framework: Hong Kong has its own regulatory system, which differs from that of mainland China, making it easier for companies to access new technologies. Limitations and Considerations While Hong Kong has significant advantages regarding access to NVIDIA GPUs, businesses must be mindful of: Evolving Geopolitical Landscape: As international dynamics shift, potential policy changes could impact access in the future. Compliance Requirements: Companies must ensure compliance with both local laws and relevant international regulations, even in Hong Kong. Conclusion Currently, Hong Kong is not subject to the same restrictions on the import of NVIDIA GPUs as applies to mainland China, making it a strategic location for establishing data centers to meet the demand for advanced computing resources. Would you like more information on logistic considerations or any other specific aspect?" It struck me in he article that the large Chinese AI companies would like to get access to NVIDIA GPU`s include our old friend Tencent(See previous RNS's about JV with Tencent subsidiary). Of course we also have links to NVIDIA through their connect programme. Seems we could be in the sweet spot. Anyway all putting 2 + 2 together and getting 5 and who knows if GPT speaks with forked tongue. Certainly interesting times ahead. GLA DYOR

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: The latest announcements from Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (LSE: SCGL) directly align with the SEA-VOO AI ASIA initiative by transitioning it from a conceptual partnership into an active, operational phase. In short, the recent updates move SEA-VOO from a "strategic vision" to a technically-backed, well-funded project with a clear path to market through established engineering partners. Key points of alignment include: Platform Development: Sealand selected Vacuumlabs as the strategic development partner for the SEA-VOO rollout. Vacuumlabs will build the technical infrastructure to integrate EVOO's AI with Sealand’s payment and distribution systems. Expansion of AI Scope: While SEA-VOO was originally focused on a "best-in-class luxury commerce experience", the latest updates expand this to include AI-driven SaaS digital management tools. This allows Sealand to offer business-to-business (B2B) services alongside its consumer-facing e-commerce platform. Infrastructure & Technical Validation: The alignment is further strengthened by EVOO AI’s acceptance into the NVIDIA Connect Program. This provides SEA-VOO with advanced AI tools and reduced computing costs, accelerating the roadmap for AI-powered personalization in the luxury market. Operational "Dual-Hub" Strategy: Sealand’s move to establish hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong provides the physical and legal framework needed for SEA-VOO to target the broader APAC market while maintaining exclusive rights to EVOO’s Olive technology in the region. Leadership for Scaling: Recent appointments, including a new CFO and Independent Non-Executive Director with cross-border transaction expertise, are designed to oversee the financial and strategic scaling of the SEA-VOO venture.

data.author: crober33
data.content: This RNS shouldn’t be dismissed as “just words” — it actually ties together everything we’ve seen recently. For the first time, SCGL has formally locked in: • AI + SaaS as the core focus • computing power + energy infrastructure • Asia-Pacific as the execution base • and explicit consideration of synergistic M&A That explains the recent CFO and Audit Chair appointments perfectly. You don’t bring in IPO, cross-border M&A and capital-markets specialists unless you’re planning something more ambitious than business-as-usual. The mention of: “integrated platform spanning digitalisation, intelligence, computing support and energy assurance” …is a huge step up from a single-project narrative. This positions SCGL as a platform vehicle, not a punt on one app. At a ~£4m market cap, the market is still valuing SCGL as if none of this matters. But companies don’t publish a prospectus, restructure their board, pivot strategy and openly flag M&A unless they believe execution is coming. This feels like the groundwork phase before something more concrete — whether that’s asset injection, partnership, funding or corporate action. Still speculative? Yes. But dismissing this as meaningless now looks increasingly wrong. DYOR. GLA.

data.author: Colenal
data.content: OSD - I do genuinely hope so, I try never to get to angry these days, at my age it isn't good for my health, and although we all get grouchy some days it probably serves little purpose. Someone posted the other day apologising for commenting while not being invested here, personally I don't care whether someone is invested or not, I welcome all genuine opinions. The bit that gets me is when people come on with the sole intention of gloating over what I see as a possible mistake on my part, or the people who tell us 'it can't be held back any longer' every time it hits .46, before returning to .37.  Before anyone gets that excited surely they should check just how many time that situation has arisen over the last 6-7 months. I'm going to please everyone this week by watching more and saying less. Let's hope the optimists prove my view wrong and something good happens soon. Hope everyone enjoys what looks like another wet one here and good luck to you all.

data.author: Bobat123
data.content: Based on recent market information (as of early February 2026), there appears to be significant confusion or speculation regarding a £1.70 analyst price target for Sealand Capital Galaxy Ltd (SCGL). Current Price Context: As of early February 2026, SCGL shares are trading in the range of 0.30p to 0.45p (roughly £0.003 - £0.0045). The £1.70 Target: Discussions on investor forums (e.g., London South East) mention an "analyst price target range from £1.65 to £1.775". However, other investors have questioned if this is a misreading of a potential 170% increase (which would only raise the share price to ~1p) rather than a £1.70 target. Performance & Volatility: While the stock saw a massive 4,500% surge from 0.10 GBX to 4.6 GBX in late 2024/early 2025

data.author: Wulfgar
data.content: If you run a scenario like this using Ai, it does look possible: For Sealand Capital Galaxy Limited (SCGL) to reach a share price of £1 (100 GBX) from its current level of approximately 0.445p, it would require a valuation increase of over 22,000%. As of February 2026, the stock is highly speculative, with a market capitalisation of roughly £4.39 million. Potential catalysts that could drive such a significant price movement include: Artificial Intelligence (AI) Expansion: The company is undergoing a major strategic shift toward AI and high-growth technology. Successful deployment of its intended AI-led software tools and computing-power infrastructure, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region (hubs in Shenzhen and Hong Kong), could serve as a massive growth driver. Successful Acquisitions: Sealand operates as a proactive acquirer. Completing its ongoing due diligence and finalized investment in EVOO AI plc (or similar high-value tech entities) could significantly alter its fundamental value. Monetisation of "Olive": Scaling its luxury e-commerce marketplace, Olive, which uses AI learning tools for personalized shopping experiences in the luxury goods sector, could lead to the revenue growth necessary to justify a higher valuation. Turnaround in Financials: Currently, the company face severe financial weakness, including a net profit margin of -368.11% and ongoing losses (£361,985 for H1 2025). A catalyst would be achieving consistent profitability and positive cash flow, which it currently lacks. Market Speculation: Historically, SCGL has experienced massive volatility, such as a 4,500% surge within a 180-day period in late 2024/early 2025. While speculative, such momentum-driven moves often occur in low-cap stocks in high-interest sectors like AI. Key Insights High Beta: With a beta of 1.06 to 1.12, the stock is highly sensitive to broader market movements, potentially amplifying gains during bullish sentiment in the tech sector. Insider Alignment: Individual insiders own approximately 56% of the company, suggesting management's interests are closely aligned with seeing the share price rise. Risks: Reaching £1 would require an extraordinary shift in fundamentals, as the current 52-week high is 5.5p. Severe financial weaknesses and negative equity remain major hurdles. We can dream though!

data.author: callit
data.content: Colenal, you are entitled to take a cautious approach if you see fit, but that analogy doesn`t match what we have here. More like they borrowed £10 and said they would pay it back in a year, 10 months later they say hello to you but don't mention the money. They don't ask for any further money, and now you wonder will I get the £10 in a few months as promised. They haven't defaulted on the debt. If you borrowed that money from a bank you wouldn't expect them to send the debt collectors until the debt was actually not paid within agreed time limits. You wouldn't expect them to have repossessed your car before the debt was up and then said it was because you didn't contact them to say you were still going to pay what was owed. It's the act of defaulting on the act of defaulting on the debt that is important, it matters not if there is communication on some other topic and no mention of the debt. If it's not in default it's not in default. The 'Summer' date is something people got from EVOO's website. It's nothing to do with Sealand or SEAVOO, though there may be a requirement for SEAVOO to use technology developed by EVOO and a delay of EVOO may make some doubt a bit more how that technology is progressing. SUMMER launch was never RNS'd for SEAVOO. Expected news in the 4th quarter, which will be in alignment with the financial year not the calendar year I would assume. GLA DYOR

data.author: Colenal
data.content: To what extent ? A slightly higher extent than we should consider it to have gone well. If you lent someone £10 a year ago on the promise it would be repaid the next day and they disappeared until last week asking for another  £10 loan promising to repay it the next day you wouldn't believe them. I am happy  to believe that we might get get lucky here if and when the day-trippers return and pump it a bit higher than their last effort, but to get excited about that R.N.S. that talked much and said little is not for me, and I know I am not alone in thinking that way. I am fully aware that we are gambling and like everyone else I don't care what takes the S.P. up but this horse is the rank outsider in the race and all the ifs, mights or coulds will not change that no matter how much we try to talk it up. Again recently the talk has turned to sellers being finished, and MMs playing games to let their friends in. If we go back 6 months the S.P. was at a similar level and the posts were exactly the same 'MMs playing games',  'they will have to let this go soon',  'letting their friends in cheap' ,  none of those posters have been right yet but if this goes near .5 they will all scream 'this it, 1p before close.' We may get rich here but don't hold your breath. All I am saying is live in the real world.

data.author: callit
data.content: Response from AI: "Proportion of Software Projects Launched Late Approximately 90% of software projects face delays beyond their initially stated release dates. This statistic highlights the significant challenges within software development, with many factors contributing to these delays. Key Factors Contributing to Delays Late Stage Design Changes: A predominant reason cited for delays is modifications made during late stages of development, which can often be within the control of the engineering teams. Poor Estimation and Planning: Many projects suffer from inaccurate estimations regarding the time and resources needed for completion, leading to overruns. Resource Allocation Issues: Shortages in key components or issues with international shipping can also impact timelines. Breakdown of Project Success Rates Only 31% of software projects are completed on time and within budget. Around 52% are considered "challenged," meaning they either run over budget or miss deadlines but are still launched. 19% are outright failures, meaning they are abandoned entirely before launch. Conclusion The high percentage of delayed software releases points to a systemic issue in project management and estimation. Understanding these factors can help organizations improve their planning and potentially reduce the incidence of delays in future projects." So the real questions is, if 90% of software projects are launched late, to what extent should we consider delays in the launch of SEAVOO to mean it all went belly up? GLA DYOR
